Anas wants to unite our country and focus on delivering a Covid recovery parliament so we can rebuild our country with a national recovery plan.I believe this is a message that will resonate with the majority of people here in East Lothian and across Scotland in the weeks ahead.

title: alcohol-seized-youths-haddington-reports-large-gatherings
story: An increasing number of calls were made on Friday relating to youths gathering in large numbers and anti-social behaviour in the town.As a result, on Saturday afternoon and evening community police officers completed high-visibility foot and mobile patrols across the town.Officers engaged with a number of youths in the town centre, Lady Kittyrsquos Doocot and Neilson Park the youths were then dispersed and a quantity of alcohol was seized and disposed of.High-visibility patrols will continue in the area over the coming weeks.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-six-secrets-boars-rock
story: July FINN took his daughter Eilidh by the hand as he walked under the trees towards the river.Twenty-six years had passed since he was last here ndash a memory he had locked away with so many others.They walked past a prehistoric broch which Finn couldnrsquot remember seeing last time. His aunt would have surely pointed it out to him. Then he read the information board and realised it was a recent reconstruction. The name of the nearby cafe now made sense to him.On the path that followed the old railway line, Finn stopped. There it was, hersquod found it: the oak tree. It still looked young, standing guard over the pebbly beach with multiple spreading branches and the magisterial presence Finn remembered.His daughter headed immediately to the waterrsquos edge. It was a much busier place now, with frequent walkers on the nearby path.There was a suspension footbridge spanning the river which Finn couldnrsquot recall. A couple walking by paused for a moment but didnrsquot come to the beach. Perhaps social distancing had some benefits, thought Finn.While his daughter played, he tried to identy the spot he had spent that first night of storytelling with his aunt.ldquoHere, right here, he whispered to himself.Time and space fused together as he imagined going back to the past to explain to his -year-old self what that evening of tales around the fire had really meant.But he would not have been able to listen, not even to his older self. His world then was a broken mirror with vital pieces missing in which he could see only part of himself those pieces lost to him forever. Guilt and anger clawed at Finnrsquos gut, rousing his depression from its slumber.He felt the dark creature trying to pull him down, pain taking over. No, not now, he thought, not in the presence of his daughter.He would not submit to it, refused to feed it with more ruminations.He wonderedhe should have taken Eilidh on this pilgrimage of healing. But yes, her presence with him, and his love for her, was the light in his soul that kept the dark creature at bay.He would be present for her and walk with her to the summit of the faerie hill. She wanted to leave the faeries a gt and a wish. Finn did too.ldquoYou ready for that walk up the faerie hill  he called out to his daughter. She nodded excitedly with a joyful smile.September Finnrsquos phone call to his mum before they left Strathyre suggested he was coping with the temporary separation. He hadnrsquot wanted to climb the faerie hill, but Izzy hoped hersquod be up for a walk up to the rock of the boar when they got to Balquhidder.It was still early morning as they crossed the old Stron Bridge and a stunning view of Loch Voil greeted them.Mist spiralled from the water and swirled around the trees on the steep braes either side. But it was already warm, with more blue sky than grey above the mist. It was set to be one of those glorious September sunny days, the kind you appreciate all the more because you know it may be the last for a long time. They stood awhile watching the mist play above the loch, as the mountains slowly revealed themselves. The Highlands wake slowly in the morning.Izzyrsquos soul tingled as she soaked in the beauty of the moment and breathed in the sweet air.ldquoCan you smell that Finn, the scent of the Highlands  she said.Finn raised his head and snfed: ldquoSmells like cow dung.He was right, it did now. A waft of it came from a nearby field where cattle grazed. Izzy laughed.ldquoAye, well, thatrsquos the historic smell of the Highlands too!She led Finn back to the old bridge they had just driven over. Its three arches spanned the river with historic elegance.They sat on the walls looking down at the water and Izzy took it as an opportunity to tell Finn about the drovers, how in days of old they would come this way, driving hundreds of cows to markets in the south, crossing rivers and traversing through glens.Theyrsquod often sleep outside with the cattle, or sometimes in droversrsquo inns. They were the cowboys of the old Highlands, who knew the land and the dferent hazards of each route, but didnrsquot wear Stetsons of course, and rarely had a horse.She pointed towards the hills to the north: ldquoOver there was a droversrsquo route, bringing the cattle this way. The drovers could veer round and steer the cattle east of the river, but with this bridge theyrsquod have been able to cross here, then again at Strathyre downriver. There were lots of dferent ways, and the drovers had detailed maps inside their heads drawn by experience. Cattle were so valuable they would often be lted by one clan from another.Finn looked bemused.ldquoLted  Like carried on their shoulders  Izzy burst out laughing at the image and Finn looked hurt.ldquoAw, sorry Finn, I wasnrsquot laughing at you, I was laughing at the image you painted in my imagination. Lted means, well, stolen. But people called it lting because it was seen as a tradition rather than a crime. At least by those doing the lting!Finn looked around, still feeling a bit raw by his auntrsquos reaction to his question.ldquoI havenrsquot watched TV for a whole day now, he said, realising hersquod missed his breakfast TV programme. He picked up a pebble and dropped it into the water below, then watched the circles expand.ldquoWhere we going today  he asked.ldquoWell, letrsquos see how far we get, but right now we are heading for Balquhidder Kirk!ldquoWhere the minister who wrote the book on faeries was ldquoAye, but there is much more to its story.Izzy took her rucksack from the roof box.ldquoSo we are walking there ldquoYep, itrsquos really not far, his aunt replied.But Finn was wary. Her rucksack seemed suspiciously full for a short walk.They set off along the quiet single track road. The air buzzed with le and mooing from the cattle had replaced the sound of traffic. Soon they had crossed a small old bridge and were heading into a wood. They were at the base of Kirton Glen and the sound of a waterfall touched Finnrsquos senses.Izzy paused only briefly at the falls but Finn wanted to linger.ldquoWersquoll come back this way, and then we can spend some time here, she said.She pointed ahead of her: ldquoJust there, through the trees, is where we are headed. I always think this is the best way to approach this ancient place to emerge from a wood after being doused with the sound of running water, rather than just arrive from a car park and... well, yoursquoll see.The path opened up onto a gravel drive and a Victorian church. He followed Izzy round the corner of the church and found himself standing on the edge of an ancient graveyard.Old gravestones littered the ground, which was uneven. A gravestone in the form of an ancient Celtic cross stood out against the blue sky.Generation upon generation lay beneath his feet. The graves surrounded the ruins of a th-century kirk. The historic site was framed by distant mountains. His aunt was right about the approach Finn felt like Indiana Jones emerging from the jungle to discover a long-lost ruined temple.Izzy led Finn carefully past the graves and into the ruins, then through the open doorway of the old kirk. Before them were three old recumbent gravestones lying side by side, surrounded by a low metal railing.A modern-looking gravestone above the graves had an inscription: ldquoMacGregor Despite them.Finn read the smaller inscriptions. They told that these were the graves of Rob Roy, his we and two of his sons. Someone had laid flowers at the foot of the graves.ldquoHe was a legendary outlaw, explained Izzy, ldquoa member of the MacGregor clan, who were hunted like the wolf.ldquoWhy ldquoThe whole clan was outlawed, which is why there is that inscription, which means despite their persecution they survived. Rob Roy lived part of his le as a hunted man, some say he was the enemy of the rich and a defender of the poor. Irsquove heard him called Scotlandrsquos Robin Hood.ldquoSo he was a hero.ldquoWell, he is to some. But to others he was a villain, a thief and a nasty killer.ldquoWhich is true, was he a goodie or a baddie ldquoPerhaps a bit of both, depending on who you are and what you believe.ldquoWhat do you believe aunty  asked Finn. Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoWell, I love the romantic stories about him, like how he gave the minister here a sheep and cow each year infor him not increasing his fees to the local people.ldquo The fact the animals were probably lted didnrsquot seem to bother the minister. People want these stories to be true because we want our heroes to be always heroic and good, and not disappoint us. But other stories show him in a very ugly light.ldquo I want him to be a hero, said Finn, ldquobut now I donrsquot know what to believe.ldquoPerhaps we can admit to ourselves that even our heroes arenrsquot always perfect and have flaws, and so sometimes they do the wrong things.Finn shrugged his shoulders: ldquoWhatrsquos flaws ldquoErm, an imperfection, or fault.Finn looked down and scuffed the ground with his boots. Izzy knew this was a challenge to how he saw the world.ldquoI want to show you something , she said.She led him to the edge of the graveyard, then pointed up at a rocky ridge which emerged from a wood on a steep brae above them.ldquoCan you see, up there, the clf face with the ledge above  Thatrsquos called Creag an Tuirc, which means the rock of the boar. It looks out over the glen and was the clan rallying point for the MacLarens who lived here. Itrsquos a special place, Irsquom hoping you will chum me up to it. I have snacks we can have when we get there.Finn looked unsure. It seemed a steep uphill walk.ldquoItrsquos a place that knows the secrets of this glen because itrsquos quietly seen everything.ldquoSecrets ldquoAye, like the mystery of Rob Royrsquos grave, and what really happened when those Buchanan clansmen arrived here looking for a fight.ldquoWhat mystery Izzy just gave Finn a teasing smile.ldquoAnd it gives you amazing views. she added.ldquoAs good as from that Celtic fort and the giantrsquos stone yesterday  asked Finn, who was wavering.ldquoIrsquod say even better.Finn ed her smile with a cheeky one: ldquoCan I have a snack now to give me energy Izzy chuckled: ldquoSure!She put her rucksack down, and took out a chocolate bar: ldquoHow about this Izzy pulled on her rucksack and started to walk out the graveyard. Finn followed while enjoying the bar.They walked together up the path that leads to Creag an Tuirc.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four and five.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-march-15-19-1996-1971-1921
story: THE sea was ldquolashing buildings in Dunbar, reported the East Lothian Courier on March , .Dunbarrsquos pound. million improved sewerage system is blamed for a catalogue of disasters along the coastline.In , the regional council cut through four metres of rock to lay two new sets of pipes and, according to residents, the sea has been ldquolashing the buildings ndash causing considerable damage ndash ever since.They claim that the natural defences were never properly replaced after the construction work, leaving their homes exposed to the mercy of the high tides.Owner of The Courtyard Hotel and Restaurant, Peter Bramley, has made repeated complaints to the council since .ldquoSomethingrsquos got to be done, he said. ldquoItrsquos seriously affecting peoplersquos business and health. When therersquos a high tide itrsquos impossible to sleep at night and therefore impossible for me to take a resident.Mr Bramley was advised in a letter from the region in November  that it planned to place two tonne blocks on the beach to stop the force of the waves ldquoin the near future.GERMAN filmmakers were in East Lothian making a cartoon, told The Haddingtonshire Courier of March , .It would appear that East Lothian is becoming a venue for professional filmmakers.Last week, Gford was visited by the West Deutsche Runfunk of Cologneunit, to film scenes for a cartoon entitled ldquoRobbi Unt Tobbi, a thriller, similar to ldquoThunderbirds.German TV prefer authentic locations for their films, and prior to their visit to Gford had been filming in the Loch Ness area.They also used a helicopter for aerial shots of the two places.Gford was chosen because of its layout, which suited the story, which they hope to complete by the end of the year, when it will appear on German TV.A MAN appeared in court charged with being disorderly while drunk in Cockenzie, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on March , .At a Justice of Peace Court, held in Haddington, on Monday ndash Mr D. Russell, Tranent, on the bench ndash James Reid, miner, Port Seton, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday, th February, behaved in a disorderly manner in the Gardenersrsquo Close, Cockenzie, while in a state of intoxication.The accused said, while he had been indulging in liquor, he was not extra drunk.The Fiscal described the language the accused had used as pretty bad, and he was ordered to pay a fine of pound, with the option of  daysrsquo imprisonment.

title: covid-scotland-staycation-foreign-holiday-rules-explained
story: And while many were overjoyed to hear news of theof pubs, gyms and hairdressers, many eyes were on suggestion around holidays this year.Under the current lsquostay at homersquo restrictions, itrsquos against the law to leave your local authority except for essential purposes.This is set to change to lsquostay localrsquo guidance on April , hopefully for no longer than three weeks.Speaking to MSPs on Tuesday, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWe expect that from April , restrictions on journeys within mainland Scotland will be lted entirely.It is also expected that tourist accommodation will be re-opened from this date, allowing for staycations once again this summer.For some types of accommodation, like self-catering, restrictions will remain for rules around the mixing of households. The First Minister added that the ldquohope is that restrictions between Scotland and other parts of the UK can be lted on that date or ldquoas soon as possible thereafter ndash but this is ldquobeing kept under review.From  April, lockdown restrictions in Scotland will begin to be eased.Watch FM @NicolaSturgeon explain these changes ##See more, including future dates for easing, at https:t.co XabMrdBXjt.Dates are dependent on scientic evidence that it is safe to ease further. pic EzFzMQqceThe First Minister said there ldquomay be a need to retain some restrictions on travel to and from the mainland in order to protect island communities from the importation of new cases.She added: ldquoRather than impose that decision now on our island communities, we intend to discuss it directly with them to determine what arrangements they consider will work best for their circumstances.Ms Sturgeon told MSPs: ldquoReducing the risk of importing new cases ndash and new iants - is also directly relevant to the issue of international travel.She said that, like the UK Government, she is ldquocertain that this will not be achievable before May .ldquoHowever, our view is that it may well not be possible for a further period after that.ldquoAnd, even when overseas travel does resume, it is very likely that a requirement for pre-departure and post-arrival testing will remain in place for some time to come.

title: family-reunited-lost-wedding-pictures-1957
story: Wendy Carroll, of Port Seton, posted the photographs on social media after her husband Brian came across an album while working in the attic of their daughter Chloersquos home on Musselburghrsquos Delta Road, which she moved to one-and-a-half years ago.Wendy said: ldquoI love old photos so he brought it home for me to look at.ldquoWhen I saw them, they were gorgeous and just full of memories.She decided to track down the family but, due to the Covid- pandemic, her search was put on hold until recently, when the photos were uploaded to social media.Wendy said the response was ldquoamazing and, within half an hour, someone recognised the wedding party.The photos were of the marriage of Musselburgh woman Una McCann and Tommy Brodie , from Armadale, on June , , at Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Church, Musselburgh.Tommy was in the RAF, stationed in Ayr, and Una and her friend went on holiday to Ayr, where she met him at the Bobby Jones dance hall.Their only child, Monica Warnock , a Wallyford resident, collected the album from Wendy the next day.Wendy said: ldquoI was so happy toit to where it belonged.Mum-of-three Monica, who has four grandchildren, was delighted to have the album back, saying her parents orced and both remarried.She said that her half-brother Russell Brodie, who lives with his we Jenni in Edinburgh, had never seen a photograph of his grandmother, who was in the wedding photo, standing at the groomrsquos side.Monica said: ldquoMy mother gave me the album  years ago. My daughter Michaela Malone had the album in her house and it somehow ended up in the attic.ldquoShe moved from Delta Road to Ormiston about three years ago and it was left in the attic by mistake.ldquoNo one realised it was missing. Wendyrsquos husband was doing work in the attic when he found it.She added that, when the photos went on Facebook, her cousins alerted her.Una , a great-grandmother-of-five, now , lives in Edinburghrsquos Craigentinny with her husband Jack. Tommy passed away in .Monica said: ldquoI took the album to my mum and she enjoyed looking at the old photographs of her family. I will keep it safe for the family to keep through the generations.

title: east-lothian-welcomes-new-lord-lieutenant
story: Mr Urquhart, of Samuelston, succeeded Michael Williams, who had been in the role for eight years, on Monday.The Lord Lieutenant is Her Majesty The Queenrsquos representative in the county, with deputies also in place to carry out duties when the Lord Lieutenant is unavailable.Mr Urquhart, , praised the efforts of his predecessor and said: ldquoIt was a real honour for me to become Lord Lieutenant for East Lothian and to receive the Lord Lieutenantrsquos sword from Michael Williams, who retired as Lord Lieutenant on Monday upon his th birthday.ldquoIn the evening, the Deputy Lieutenants had an enjoyable Zoom meeting with Michael and his we Barbara.ldquoWe took the opportunity to pass on our thanks to Michael for all his work and devotion to duty over the last seven years as Lord Lieutenant.ldquoMichael gave very generously of his time and he immersed himself in community and voluntary le across the county.ldquoHe provided a lot of support and encouragement to the very many iniduals and voluntary organisations he came across and became involved in.Mr Urquhart also praised the efforts of his deputies and East Lothian Council.He added: ldquoI look forward to enhancing and building upon all the good work that the lieutenancy does in the county and look forward to helping spread the word as to what the lieutenancy does and can do for the people of East Lothian.Mr Williams told the Courier that his final day in the role had been ldquoquite emotional.He said: ldquoI have been so fortunate to do it, really.ldquoIt is dficult to sum it up: I was so incredibly privileged to meet so many wonderful people and to serve Her Majesty The Queen in the county.ldquoI just never would have met all these peopleI did not do that. It has been outstanding and just such an opportunity.Mr Williams offered thanks to the community for their support over the years and thanked the cadets who had also been involved.Marking his retirement, the countyrsquos Deputy Lieutenantspresented Mr Williams with a gt.He said: ldquoMy DLs have given me a mulberry tree to plant, which was very, very kind of them.ldquoIrsquom on a farm and my daughter Nicola Kay is farming it and she has already given me two or three jobs.Provost John McMillan paid tribute to the Mr Williams.Mr McMillan said: ldquoHis thoughtfulness and kindness and genuine interest in our communities in East Lothian have marked him out as an exceptional representative of Her Majesty.ldquoI have watched him at many events, informal and formal, quietly engage with everyone.ldquoHe helped to make people feel at ease and special during citizenship and medal ceremonies, most memorably when he organised the award to Scott Glynn of his MBE in the provostrsquos office, even lending his sword to Scott for photos.ldquoMichaelrsquos work with cadets and reserve forces and with veterans took him back to his roots, and he valued and promoted all of those structures.ldquoIn promoting East Lothian, our Lord Lieutenant has worked to recognise volunteers and enterprises, with nominations for Queenrsquos Awards being received and appreciated throughout the county.ldquoHe and the team he created have done so much to engender community spirit and his words in the recent video thanking volunteers for their efforts are typical of his interest and sincerity.ldquoI shall miss Michaelrsquos wit and wisdom and dignied presence at remembrance ceremonies, and events such as the Silver Arrow Shoot and provostrsquos reception.And he added: ldquoBarbara and his family have supported him so much, and seeing them all together, marking fetes and anniversaries at YesterSchool, is a mark of Michaelrsquos strong sense of family and community values.Iain Gray, East Lothianrsquos MSP, also offered some kind words.He said: ldquoMichael Williams has been an outstanding representative for East Lothian for nearly  years, in his current role and previously as Deputy Lieutenant and Vice Lord Lieutenant.ldquoI thank him for his diligent service to our county and wish him well in his retirement.ldquoI know that Roderick Urquhart will bring the same level of commitment, enthusiasm and local knowledge to the position and wish him every success in his new role.

title: nicola-sturgeon-misled-parliament---mean-comes-next
story: The Holyrood inquiry into the affair found the First Minister gave "an inaccurate account" of her actions and so misled the cross-party investigation.However, it stopped short of saying she did so "knowingly", the threshold for resignation under the Scottish Ministerial Code.It is understood the inquiry split down party lines - on the issue on Thursday, and decided Ms Sturgeon broke the code on the balance of probabilities, with only SNP MSPs clearing their leader.Why was the committee established It was set up after a successful judicial review by former first minister Mr Salmond resulted in the Scottish Governmentrsquos investigation of harassment allegations against him being ruled unlawful and ldquotainted by apparent bias, with a pound, payout being awarded to him for legal fees in .MSPs have taken evidence from Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon, from civil servants, including repeated sessions from Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans, trade unions and from SNP chief executive Peter Murrell ndash who is current First Minister Ms Sturgeonrsquos husband.Why did Mr Salmond take legal action The former first minister did not feel his treatment by the Scottish Government was fair.It was later found that the lead investigator of the complaints had prior contact with some of the female complainers, leading Judge Lord Pentland to say the investigation was ldquotainted with apparent bias.How has the inquiry gone The committee has repeatedly voiced frustration about the slow handing over of evidence from a number of parties.The Scottish Government was accused of obstruction last year, with the committee saying it was ldquocompletely frustrated with the lack of evidence.Both the committee and the Scottish Government were at loggerheads over legal advice provided as part of the judicial review process. MSPs wanted to know when the Scottish Government was advised it would likely lose the challenge raised by Mr Salmond, but ministers said handing over the advice would breach the ministerial code.On two occasions, MSPs voted for the evidence to be released, with a deal eventually being struck in December to reveal the advice only to MSPs on the committee.Following a vote of no confidence threat in the Deputy First Minister, the Scottish Government released ldquokey legal advice, but the Scottish Tories were not satisfied and continued in their bid to oust John Swinney, which ultimately failed.Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon separately sat for mammoth sessions in front of the committee, taking questions from MSPs over several hours.Didnrsquot Mr Salmond face trial on sexual misconduct charges Yes. The former first minister was cleared of  charges at the High Court in Edinburgh in March last year after being arrested in January .What were the issues with Mr Salmondrsquos evidence to the committee Mr Salmond and the committee have been caught in repeated legal wrangles over evidence published by the inquiry.Last month, the former first minister said he would not appear before the committee after it decided not to publish his submission to a separate investigation into whether Ms Sturgeon breached the ministerial code over fears it may identy some of the complainers in Mr Salmondrsquos criminal trial last year.However, an alteration made to a court order by Judge Lady Dorrian meant the evidence could potentially be made public.While the committee voted against publication, the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Bodymade the decision to publish anyway.The evidence was online for less than  hours before the Crown Office raised concerns with Holyrood about it, asking for redactions to be made.In his submission, the former first minister accused some in the Scottish Government and SNP of a ldquomalicious and concerted attempt to damage my reputation and remove me from public le in Scotland.But Ms Sturgeon said her predecessor did not have ldquoa shred of evidence to support his claims.The submission was later re-released, with a number of paragraphs relating to the set-up of a meeting between Mr Salmond and his successor redacted.Is the committee inquiry the only investigation into the matter No. Ms Sturgeon is currently under investigation by James Hamilton QC to establishshe breached the ministerial code.Ms Sturgeon referred herself after being accused of misleading Parliament over when she knew of the complaints against Mr Salmond.She previously said she had been told about the allegations by Mr Salmond himself during a meeting in her home on April , .However, it was later found that Mr Salmondrsquos former chief of staff Geoff Aberdein had met with the First Minister in her Holyrood office four days prior to that, where she was told of the complaints.Scotlandrsquos first minister @NicolaSturgeon responds to @SkyNews exclusive the harassment committee has ruled she misled Parliament in her evidence.ldquoThe opposition members of this committee made their minds up about me before I uttered a single word of evidence. pic UNeUJsWhat has the committee concluded A leak on Thursday evening from inside the committee revealed it has concluded the First Minister misled the inquiry over whether she had offered to intervene in the case ndash which Ms Sturgeon denies doing.Two other witnesses, one of whom is Mr Salmondrsquos lawyer and former SNP MSP Duncan Hamilton and who was at the meeting in question, contradicted the First Ministerrsquos statement.The conclusion was arrived at following a - party line vote, with the four SNP members of the committee, including convener Linda Fabiani, supporting the First Ministerrsquos assertion.What happens next The decision is likely to increase pressure on Ms Sturgeon to stand down before Mayrsquos election, although it is unclear whether the act was deemed a resignation-worthy offence.Last night, Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross called for her to quit.He said: ldquoThe committee will publish its findings in the coming days and we will wait for that report.ldquoBut we have already detailed that Nicola Sturgeon lied to the Scottish Parliament and for that, she must resign. All wersquore waiting for is confirmation.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar said: ldquoI am not going to prejudge the outcome of the committee report and we await its findings, butit does conclude that the First Minister has misled Parliament and potentially breached the ministerial code then that is incredibly serious.A Scottish Parliament spokesperson said: "Further to media reports on the Committeersquos findings, the Committee is still finalising its report. There will be no further comment on the report ahead of its publication.It is expected to be published on Tuesday.What has Nicola Sturgeon said Nicola Sturgeon has said a ldquovery partisan leak from the Alex Salmond inquiry is ldquonot that surprising as the committee is understood to have deemed she misled parliament.She told Sky News last night: ldquoI stand by all of the evidence I gave to the committee, all eight hoursrsquo worth of evidence.ldquoWhatrsquos been clear is that opposition members of this committee made their minds up about me before I muttered a single word of evidence, their public comments have made that clear.ldquoSo this leak from the committee ndash very partisan leak ndash tonight before theyrsquove finalised the report is not that surprising.She added that she is awaiting the result of the James Hamilton QC investigation into whether she broke the ministerial code.A spokesman for the First Minister previously added: ldquoThe First Minister told the truth to the committee in eight hours of evidence, and stands by that evidence.ldquoIt is clear from past public statements that opposition members of this committee had prejudged the First Minister at the outset of the inquiry and before hearing a word of her evidence, so this partisan and selective briefing ndash before the committee has actually published its final report ndash is hardly surprising.ldquoThe question of the First Ministerrsquos adherence to the ministerial code is being considered independently by James Hamilton, and we expect to receive and publish his report soon.

title: musselburgh-sea-cadets-virtual-walk-london-back
story: Along with family members, they are logging their steps or kilometres, completed daily during March, via an online tracker which calculates the distance walked for each day.They had originally planned to walk km, from Musselburgh to London, but smashed their target distance and started thejourney back to the Honest Toun ndash a total of ,km.They have already raised nearly pound,.Chief Officer Mark Tfin , from Gorebridge, is supporting the unit ndash TS Indefatigable ndash by taking part in the virtual sponsored walk while on his Maersk Line Hamburg Sud ship off Chinarsquos coast, covering more than km.Funds raised will be used to provide training when the cadetsto their newly refurbished unit building on South Street after Covid- restrictions are eased.The property has undergone a full upgrade costing pound, to include new toilet and shower facilities, offices and classroom space. Improved teaching equipment such as interactive teaching boards have also been installed.Funding of pound, was received from the Marine Society and Sea Cadets, pound, from Viridor, pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund and pound, from fundraising and donations.Petty Officer Belle Milliken said: ldquoDue to the current pandemic, the unit has lost out on a lot of our usual fundraising route and, with the team taking part in the sponsored walk, it will enable them to get out, get fit, improve wellbeing and spend time with family as part of their team.She said: ldquoThe money will support ourto parading, purchasing training equipment for the cadets in face-to-face classes, and upkeep for the current equipment and boats.The group provides --year-olds with a range of opportunities, from first aid to boating qualications, all based around the Royal Navy.PO Milliken said the cadets were looking forward to ing to normal activities after the Covid- crisis.She said: ldquoWe were hoping tolate last year but, due to awaiting final certication for the building work, this was put on hold.ldquoAt the moment we are parading as normal but on Zoom and delivering specialisation training in communication systems, promotion training, first aid, engineering, Duke of Edinburgh, boating theory, catering, BTEC and CVQO.ldquoWe have also had sessions delivered by the Royal Navy engagement team on careers and flags at sea, which is a Royal Navy communication session.One cadet said: ldquoPersonally, joining sea cadets was one of the best things I have done.ldquoIt has provided me with a confidence and experiences that just simply cannot be learnt within a classroom.ldquoIt has given me an insight into Royal Navy le and has helped me meet many friends from all across the UK who will be friends for le.Anyone wishing to donate to the sponsored walk can go to gofundme f musselburgh-sea-cadets-sponsored-virtual-walk-

title: teenager-launches-petition-bins-wallyford
story: While out walking his Jack Russell terrier Madi, Corgan James-Robertson, , noticed a shortage of bins around the village after moving there with his family in March last year.He is concerned about the amount of dog dirt and poo bags left lying around, as well as rubbish including plastic items such as bottles.He hopes the petition, which currently has more than  signatures, will encourage the council to provide more bins in the area.Corgan, a pupil at Portobello High School, said that there were recycling bins everywhere in Portobello, where he used to live, so it was easy to dispose of drink bottles and cans.He said: ldquoIn Wallyford there are none and only one rubbish bin ndash not even the bus stops have bins near them.He added: ldquoEver since I moved to Wallyford in March , I have noticed that there is a shortage of bins around Wallyford.ldquoThere is a lot of dog faeces, plastics rubbish and dog poo bags left lying around.ldquoI would like to get the attention of East Lothian Council to get more bins that would include recycling and rubbish.Even Madi is helping with the initiative, as the environmentally conscious canine always recycles a discarded bottle while out for a walk by bringing one home each time .Corganrsquos mum Samantha said: ldquoWe just noticed that there were so many lying everywhere.Corgan decided to take action and has sent his petition to local MSP Colin Beattie, and plans to write to East Lothian Council at the end of his campaign.The family are ldquofirm believers in recycling and the effects of discarded plastic bottles and bags on the environment.The petition is available to view online at change.org p east-lothian-council-to-get-more-bins-in-wallyford

title: call-new-fishmongers-open-haddington
story: Haddington has been without a permanent fishmonger for a number of years, with the town visited by two mobile fish vans which stop off three times each week.Now, members of the townrsquos community council are debating whether the increased use of fresh food, including fish, in cooking would tip the scale in favour of a new shop.A number of community councillors told a virtual meeting that they used the vans when they came to the town, with many members equally convinced that a shop would do well.Therese Laing felt that times had changed and people were buying more fresh goods, including fish.Pat Lemmon, vice-chairwoman of the group, added: ldquoIf there was a market for a fish shop or a fruit and veg shop, it would be lovely to see them in the town centre.The town centre currently has very few empty units, despite the challenges brought by the coronavirus pandemic.Fiona Frances-Adams, also a community councillor, was among those who felt a quality fishmonger could be successful in Haddington.She said a previous fishmonger had not stocked much shellfish, adding: ldquoThey said there was no market for it.ldquoIf you donrsquot try the market, there will not be one. I still thinkyou get a fish shop with a lot more choice, top choice, like Clark Bros in Musselburgh on a smaller scale, it would do very well.Fellow member Jack Worden stressed that the quality of the seafood on offer was crucial to determiningthe business would be a success.He said: ldquoI sadly did not go into the fish shop but go to the fish van because the quality is so much better. If there is a market for a fish shop, it will come.Despite the debate, Chris McEwan, chairman of the group, stressed that the idea was outwith their remit.He said: ldquoThe community council does not really do fish shops! It is the sort of thing that would have to work with councillors and council. Maybe the next time a fish van is there, mention to them they would make a roaring tradethere was a shop.Carolyn Algeo ran JC Seafood and Paulrsquos Fish Shop, alongside husband Paul, in the town centre until about .She now runs JC Seafood in Port Seton and felt the increasing number of fish vans meant it would be dficult for a permanent fishmongerrsquos in Haddington.She said: ldquoIt would be a complete uphill struggle.ldquoThere are many vans coming in from all over the area.

title: pupils-get-insight-world-finance-apprentice-scheme
story: Pupils from Dunbar Grammar School, North Berwick High School and Preston Lodge High School have spent lockdown preparing for the world of work by undertaking foundation apprenticeships in providing financial services with Social Investment Scotland .Rachel Miller, who attends Preston Lodge Dunbar Grammar pupil Abbie Chisholm and Emma Roy, of North Berwick High, have been working towards the qualication for the last  months alongside their regular schoolwork.They have had to balance the demands of the apprenticeship programme with online learning during the pandemic.Foundation apprenticeships were launched in  to help S and S pupils gain work experience while still at school, with the qualication equivalent to an SQA Higher.They are offered to senior school pupils as part of the curriculum when making their subject choices.The pupils have already achieved a National Progression Award after completing the classroom-style learning segment of the course, which was delivered by Limelight Careers on behalf of East Lothian Council.A large part of the programme usually involves a work-based placement however, given the work-from-home guidance, many of the placements with financial services providers have been put on hold.SIS stepped in to offer the pupils an opportunity to join the team virtually.Emma, , enjoyed the experience. She said: ldquoOver the last year, regular schoolwork and exams have been so up in the air, but itrsquos been reassuring to have the apprenticeship programme going on at the same time, which will give me a formal qualication.ldquoIrsquove developed my knowledge of finance throughout the programme but have also had the opportunity to build confidence and practice other skills like teamwork and communication.SIS was one of the first financial organisations in Scotland to support this kind of foundation apprenticeship for school pupils.In the last two years, the organisation has welcomed six pupils to its team as part of their learning experience, supporting them on their journey into employment.Lindsay Wake, head of impact at SIS, said: ldquoWersquove been impressed with the pupilsrsquo resilience and willingness to learn, despite the uncertainty of the world around them, and we hope to see them continue on to exciting and rewarding careers in the financial services sector.

title: covid-scotland-lockdown-9-key-announcements-may-missed
story: The First Minister set out a series of ldquoindicative dates for the re-opening of the economy.Theof hospitality, hairdressers and gyms immediately caught the eye of the public, eager for ato some form of normality.But there are some other key points contained within the extensive route-map that people may have missed.Wersquove shared our timeline for a safe and gradual easing of restrictions in Scotland.All dates are dependent on scientic evidence that it is safe to ease further.Watch our video to find out more ##Read the timeline ## title: cant-choose-covid-vaccine-get
story: There has been a lot of discussion around the side effects of the AstraZeneca vaccine, however ministries across the globe have been quick to quash any fears saying that it is "safe and effective".Prime Minister Boris Johnson will receive the Oxford jabas he urges the country to get vaccinated.The news of Mr Johnson receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine comes as a host of European countries announced they would begin using the jab once again following new safety assurances.A number of countries including Germany and France have reversed their decision to temporarily pause the use of the AstraZeneca vaccine over blood clot concerns after the European Medicines Agencycalled the vaccine ldquosafe and effective.France, Italy and Germany, along with Cyprus, Latvia and Lithuania, have confirmed they will resume rollout of the Oxford shot on Friday.While Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands said they will follow suit next week, although Spain said it could exclude certain groups.But do you have a choice in the matter  Can you pick and choose which of the currently approved vaccines you are injected withyou have worries about a particular one Here is everything you need to know about it:No.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation has not advised a preference between the Pfizer-BioNTech, the Oxford-AstraZeneca or any other vaccines in the UKpopulation, stating that "both give very high protection against severe disease... and both vaccines have good safety profiles".The UKrsquos vaccine programme is offering vaccines in line with the supply of vaccines, and so the option to choose is not availablesay the NHS.In certain circumstances, you may be advised to have a certain vaccine by a medical professional, but this is not common, and will be discussed with you fully before hand you cannot request a certain vaccine for yourself.Earlier this week, Northern Irelandrsquos Health Minister made clear people cannot pick and choose what type of Covid- vaccine they receive as he moved to provide reassurance on the safety of the AstraZeneca jab.Robin Swann highlighted that the UKrsquos Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyhad found no evidence of a link between the vaccine and reported cases of blood clots in some European countries.Asked whether people who had concerns about the AstraZeneca jab could select a dferent type of vaccine, Swann said, ldquotherersquos no opportunity to pick and choose vaccines within our current programme.You will have to have two doses of the same vaccine.The MHRA has concluded that any link between the jab and clots is unproven The World Health Organisationis urging countries to continue using the AstraZeneca Covid- vaccine as global medical leaders meet to discuss reports of blood clots.Dr Soumya Swaminathan, WHOrsquos chief scientist, told a media briefing ldquowe do not want people to panic, as she said no association has been found so far between blood clots and Covid- vaccines.She said the rates at which blood clots have occurred in people who received the AstraZeneca vaccine ldquoare in fact less than what you would expect in the general population.Professor Anthony Harnden, deputy chairman of the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation, said there was ldquono demonstrable dference in the number of blood clots seen between the general population and the  million who have so far received the Oxford AstraZeneca jab to date.He told BBC Breakfast ldquobecause wersquore immunising so many people, we are bound to see blood clots at the same time as the vaccination.ldquoThatrsquos not because they are due to the vaccination. Thatrsquos because they occur naturally in the population. We have to remember that there are , blood clots a month on average in the general population.ldquoOne ought to also remember that Covid causes blood clots, added Prof Harnden. ldquoSo, the risks of not having the Covid vaccination far outweigh the risks from the vaccinations.The EMA has concluded there is no overall increase in the risk of blood clots with the vaccine Of course, taking up the offer of a Covid- vaccine remains voluntary, and there are currently no plans to make being immunised.But members of the public are being urged to accept offers of a jab as soon as they can, and being reassured that all vaccines available are safe, and have been developed under the usual strict, regulatory practices.Peter Openshaw, professor of experimental medicine at Imperial College London, said the decision to pause rollout of the Oxford AstraZeneca jab could be a ldquodisaster for Covid- vaccine uptake in Europe.Asked what he would say to those in the UK who are booked to receive an Oxford jab, Prof Openshaw told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoI really wouldnrsquot be worried at the present time.ldquoI think it is very clear that the benefits of being vaccinated at the moment so far outweigh the possible concern over this rather rare type of blood clot, he added. ldquoI think it is a disaster for the vaccination uptake in Europe, which is already on slightly unsteady ground in some countries.

title: old-firm-coronavirus-avoid-disgraceful-scenes-brian-taylor
story: This week a new challenge emerged to those endeavours, a new problem from the world of football. That problem continues to pose concerns, not least over whether the sizeable gatherings outside Ibrox and in Glasgowrsquos George Square might be repeated, perhaps at the upcoming Old Firm match.I watched Celtic draw with Dundee United last weekend, a result which guaranteed the Premiership for Rangers. Football fans will perhaps understand that my first thought was that my team, United, now had virtually no chance of securing a top six place in the league, and thus avoiding a possible relegation battle. BRIAN TAYLOR:This is not a civil war in the SNP. This is more vicious and more visceralHowever, the wider consequences soon emerged as Rangers fans mustered to celebrate their teamrsquos success, in clear breach of rules prohibiting mass gatherings.Condemnation was swt from the First Minister, Opposition leaders and the police. While praising Rangersrsquo sporting achievement, they declared that the supportersrsquo actions were unacceptable and dangerous. They reminded us bluntly that closely packed crowds had the potential to spread disease and even death.Let us be clear. Parliament has the democratic power to prescribe rules. Within those rules, the police have a duty to proscribe behaviour which threatens the peace and, in this case, the health of citizens. Law and order must be maintained.The question is how. What is the truly effective way to prevent repetition  To do that, we need to understand the motivations underlying the behaviour we all witnessed.Otherwise, we risk making matters worse, we risk reinforcing a negative stereotype. To say this is in no way ndash I stress, in no way whatsoever ndash to condone the behaviour on display. It was dangerous and, potentially, deadly.Nicola Sturgeon has warned the Old FirmFirstly, I would broadly exculpate the police. You will hear it said either that they over-reacted or that they should have made far more arrests.The police did not create the situation. The fans gathered instinctively, emotively, no doubt prompted by social media. The police had to deal with events as they found them.An over-zealous response would have risked provoking the crowd, amplying the challenge to public order. Precisely the opposite of what the police were seeking to achieve.Secondly, consider the intrinsic nature of football support. We are dealing here with fans, or fanatics. For many, their le is defined by their vigorous adherence to their team. They exult in victory, they despair at defeat.This particular triumph for Rangers followed a decade without winning the league title a decade in which they had to rise from the lowest rank in Scottish football. In winning, they thwarted their greatest rivals.More generally, many fans regard their support for their team in an antithetical fashion to rival clubs, or even to society more generally. It is no accident that many supporters sing ldquonobody likes us, we donrsquot care. Their contrived self-image is as a beleaguered tribe, standing together against an external foe or an uncaring world.That is true of the most fervent of fans generally but it is particularly true of the Old Firm. Their adherents will often define themselves in contradistinction to the other side. Which can present a challenge for neutral observers or, indeed, for politicians seeking to intervene.Grimacing wryly, Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs this week that half of Glasgow presumed she was partisan for one side of the Old Firm while the other half presumed exactly the contrary. She was, she stressed, unconcerned about the colour of the shirt.It was also notable in Rangersrsquo official statement that they immediately drew attention to what they regarded as ldquoan unbalanced approach adopted towards their half of the Old Firm.In that same statement, Rangers insisted they had taken every step to pre-empt and deter such behaviour. It might be pertinent to note here that broader support for that analysis is distinctly limited. Further, eventhey were doing all they could, then those efforts demonstrably failed.Crucially, however, Rangers supporters will agree with their club. They will discern bias against them which others do not spot. Such a standpoint is not entirely unknown on the other side of the Glasgow sporting ide, nor indeed in football more generally. They are not known as fans for nothing. Once again, that does not remotely exonerate the behaviour we witnessed.However, it is also the case that there are many Rangers fans who will regret the scenes witnessed, who will seek to dispel any bad odour lingering around their clubrsquos remarkable success. As The Herald reported, supportersrsquo groups have raised thousands of pounds to repair damaged benches in George Square.Equally, though, those of us who are football fans need to reflect that many, perhaps most, people in Scotland are not. BRIAN TAYLOR:Sturgeonrsquos inquiry performance was thorough, respectful, controlled and capableRemember Brenda from Bristol  On being told that a further General Election was pending, she replied: ldquoYoursquore joking! What, another one !Translate that from Brendarsquos broad Bristol accent into Scots, and you have it pat. For many in Scotland, their reaction to another controversy in football is ennui. They find it weary, stale and flat full of sound and fury and signying nothing.In that light, we now need action which will be effective, rather than simply voluble. Perhaps a promise of substantial celebrations deferred, linked to the warning that the Old Firm game may have to be cancelled. Perhaps a reminder of possible sanctions by the European football authority.It will not be sufficient for that message to be delivered solely by politicians. Still less, by the police. That will not work with the truly zealous.Football leaders must douse their instinctive indignation and urge compliance. Consistently and without equivocation. In tandem with politicians and the police. It may be exasperating that such effort is required but anything  risks further failure. Understand, then act.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: food-baking-spreading-bit-joy-sweet-treats
story: Baking is all about spreading a bit of joy with sweet treats - something Kim-Joy Hewlett knows a thing or two about.Her signature bakes are delightful, delicious and full of cute animals and characters.A former psychological wellbeing practitioner, Kim-Joy was a finalist in series nine of The Great British Bake Off, and now dedicates her time to bringing what she calls edible cuteness to the masses.These are her food memories...Her earliest food memory is..."I grew up in Belgium. I went to nursery in Belgium for a bit - you know when you have a memory, but youre not sureit exactly happened that way  I was eating sandwiches and it was in the morning."The teacher was laughing at me because I think she thought I was eating my lunch. But in my head, I knew I wasnt eating my lunch, I just couldnt really explain it. And thats all I remember - its a bit vague."Her culinary highlight..."Definitely Bake Off stuff, but none of the technicals - I didnt like them, they were too hard. I just panicked in the technical, because I hadnt done it before, and because of the time limit, I rushed everything. I made very silly mistakes. But my culinary high is being on Bake Off and getting to the final."Favourite bake from the show..."Thats a hard one, because I like so many. In dessert week I did a chocolate ball with some choux pastry turtles inside. Thats the one people mention to me. I was so nervous about it, because I had to do a melting chocolate ball, which is really hard. Just having it work was a relief."Its probably because its the one other people like, rather than my personal favourite, but its become a personal favourite because other people like it."Kim-Joys worst kitchen disaster has to be..."There have been many, but I block them out of my brain. Ive definitely dropped a lot of stuff. All I can think about is that my kitchen was a mess this morning, so Ive been tidying it. Ive definitely successfully blocked out any fails from my brain, but there are lots of them!"Favourite meals shes cooked for other people..."Probably one Christmas, me and Nabil [her partner] did a big dinner - that was for ourselves. And I did a cake for my mum recently, just a simple chocolate cake for her birthday."Baking with Kim-Joyand Christmas With Kim-Joy: A Festive Collection Of Edible Cutenessby Kim-Joy, photography by Ellis Parrinder, are published by Quadrille. Available now.

title: motoring-plug-in-hybrids-check
story: The plug-in hybrid market is expanding rapidly. While its compact e has been a hit for some time - particularly among business users - its the latest X e which really changes things up. Its fitted with a kWh battery - far larger than many others here - which means it canup to  miles of electric-only range.But once that charge is used up, youre still left with a silky-smooth straight-six petrol engine with more than enough performance on tap. However, the X hasnt been designed to accept a rapid charge and can only be topped up at speeds of up to .kW. It means a -% charge will take over five hours.Audi A TFSI eAudi is currently hell-bent on adding plug-in hybrid versions of nearly all of its cars. title: centuries-outlander-new-military-roads-walter-scotts-poetry-brought-tourists-flocking-highlands
story: Before the great Covid upheaval it was estimated that the number of tourists visiting Scottish sites featured in the TV series Outlander had risen by % since , from , to a staggering . million in . Based on the best-selling novels by Diana Gabaldon, scenes were filmed at locations across Scotland, including Doune Castle , Blackness and Drumlanrig Castles, Newtonmore and Glen Coe in the Highlands. Gabaldon received an International Contribution to Scottish Tourism award at the Scottish Thistle awards, while VisitScotland published a paper describing the soaring numbers of Outlander ldquoset-jetters.The new tourist boom wasnt all due to Outlander . Lonely Planets Best Travel  ranked the Highlands and Islands ldquofth in the world, describing the region as ldquoone of the wildest, least inhabited, and most scenic parts of Europe, a judgement wrapped in ironies for students of Highland history. In  the launch of the North Coast  route saw the opening up of the northern Highlands to mass tourism, bringing economic benefits but also problems for residents, as single-track roads became jammed with campervans and tour buses. Visitor numbers to the Fairy Pools on the Isle of Skye doubled between  and : islanders complained of congested roads, as well as litter and human waste dumped on roadsides, partly due to lack of toilet facilities. It was reported that the proleration of Airbnb and rental cottages caused a hike in property prices, squeezing out locals.While the pandemichave put the brakes on international tourism, the easing of lockdown restrictions in the summer of  saw Scots from the Central Belt fleeing from months of urban confinement to beauty spots in the southern Highlands, while English tourists poured across the Border for Scottish ldquostaycations. In June  police had to close congested B-roads on Loch Lomond and Callander, while double yellow lines were painted on roads in the Trossachs and where to prevent parking on the verges.Yet this influx of visitors clogging up the Scottish roads infrastructure is not a modern day phenomenon as can be seen in Old Ways New Roads: Travels in Scotland -, a book I co-edited with John Bonehill and Anne Dulau Beveridge. The book accompanies a virtual exhibition hosted by The Hunterian at the University of Glasgow which opens later this spring, with a programme of public events and talks.Our title refers to a ldquotourist paradox whereby access to Scotlands ldquoold ways was only made possible by the th-century infrastructure of ldquonew roads, many constructed by the military to contain the Jacobite threat. Before then, intractable terrain, especially in the Highlands, had made many areas inaccessible and frustrated the movement of troops and supplies. The Welsh traveller Thomas Pennant claimed that Scotland had been previously ldquoas little known to its southern brethren as Kamtschatka: but once his own tours in  and  proved the country ldquomight be visited with safety ... it has ever since been [inundated] with southern visitors.Pennant was the first to describe tourists following two main itineraries, the ldquolong tour from Edinburgh to Inverness and down the Great Glen to Fort William, Skye and Mull, or  the ldquopetit tour, a fortnight circuit of the military roads through Perthshire and Argyll in a horse chaise. Highlights of the latter were the scenic, landscaped Breadalbane, Atholl and Argyll estates.As early as , Lord Breadalbane noticed that ldquoall the world is travelling to Scotland, and like other landowners weary of putting up fashionable visitors armed with letters of introduction, he opened an inn in the village of Kenmore as a base for visiting local attractions, such as the picturesque ldquoHermitage he had constructed overlooking nearby Acharn Falls.However the improvement of Highland roads and inns was only relative: in , an anonymous English tourist anticipated todayrsquos Tripadvisor phenomenon by complaining in his travel journal that Kenmore Inn was ldquodirty cold and damp and beds hard and uncomfortable, and that his party had arrived too late to view the scenery thanks to ldquothe bad state of the roads. Off the beaten track, it was even worse ndash in , the English Romantic poet John Keats had to live off eggs and whisky, sleeping in damp shepherds bothies, on his walking tour along Loch Awe and across Mull to Iona and Staffa.The closure of Europe during the war years of -, and the rise of a new British middle class, did much to stimulate ldquodomestic tourism in the Romantic period: intrepid women now joined men in exploring remoter parts of the country, keeping journals and sketchbooks, while celebrated artists like Turner and Alexander Nasmyth were among the many portraying its scenic splendours. Nonetheless, anticipating the age of Outlander, the Scottish tour was a profoundly literary phenomenon, as tourists sought out the settings of Scottish poet James Macphersons Ossian, the poems and songs of Robert Burns, or the romances of Sir Walter Scott. Landowners capitalised on such literary landscapes: in the early s, the Duke of Atholl rebranded his Dunkeld Hermitageas ldquoOssians Hall, and from his base on Ulva, Ranald Macdonald Steuart-Seton, ldquothe Laird of Staffa, supplemented his rentals by managing tourist access to Fingals Cave, the ldquojewel in the crown of the Highland tour. John Keats couldnt afford to take a boat from Oban to Staffa because the going price was an astronomical seven guineas. ldquoTis like paying d for an apple at the playhouse, he complained.Nowhere attracted tourists quite like the Trossachs, relatively accessible from Glasgow and Stirling. This was largely Scotts doing, having chosen the Trossachs as a setting for his  poem The Lady of the Lake.Scott himself first visited as a tourist, plundering the guidebooks consulted by his friends Dorothy and William Wordsworthin the poems notes. It sold , copies in the first year of publication, and, like Scotts later poems and novels, was rapidly adapted for popular theatre, opera, panoramic displays and even wallpaper designs. Seldom read today, the poem features a romance between the stag-hunter ldquoFitz-Jamesand the exiled Ellen Douglas , who dwelt on a romantic island still known as Ellens Isle on Loch Katrine.Scott gave a new resonance to Highland landscape in describing his heros view from the Trossachs: ldquoLoch Katrine lay beneath him rolld   In all herfar winding lay  With promontory, creek and bay,   And islands that, empurpled bright,  Floated amid the livelier light ...Just like Outlander ldquoset-jetters today, Scotts fans quickly made the Trossachs one of the most popular tourist sites in Europe. One female tourist estimated that more than  carriages had reached this ldquofar-famed spot in the summer of : no doubt many were parking on the verges. In  an angry Loch Lomond boatman was heard complaining that ldquoever since [Scott] wrote The Lady of the Lake ... everybody goes to that filthy hole Loch Catrine, than comes round by Luss, and I have only had two gentlemen to guide this blessed season ... The devil confound his ladies and his lakes, say I!An enterprising local farmer converted his dwelling into overnight accommodation for tourists, known as Ardcheanochrochan Inn: it was rebuilt in  as the baronial Trossachs Hotel by Lord Willoughby dEresby. Poet laureate Robert Southey, visiting in  with Thomas Telford, snidely observed that ldquo the owner of the house has a proper sense of his obligations, he will set up the sign of Walter Scotts head. But just five years later, the geologist John Macculloch complained that tourism was destroying Highland romance: ldquothe mystic portal has been thrown open, and the mob has rushed in, dispersing all these fairy visions ... barouches and gigs, cocknies and fishermen and poets, Glasgow weavers and travelling haberdashers, now swarm in every resting place.Scotts literary fame may have dipped, but his recently refurbished Abbotsford House in Melrose still makes a substantial contribution to Scottish tourism, although not on the scale of the National Trust for Scotlands Robert Burns Birthplace Museum at Alloway, Ayrshire: a  Government-commissioned report calculated Burnss annual value to the Scottish economy as around pound million, with an additional ldquobrand value at around pound million.ldquoSet-jetting has greatly boosted these traditional literary attractions, with overall tourist spending for  estimated at a staggering pound. billion. Old Ways New Roads demonstrates that the appeal of premier tourist sites like the Trossachs had as much to do with investment by canny landowners and local residents as with poetic genius. Theres a lesson here for Scottish tourism in the era of ldquostaycations and Outlander. Namely, the need for more investment in roads, parking and toilet facilities as well as accommodation and hospitality that create jobs in the underpopulated Highlands, without depriving locals of affordable homes, not to mention peace of mind.Nigel Leask is Regius Professor of English Language and Literature at the University of Glasgow and an expert on Romanticism, empire and travel writingOld Ways and New Roads: Travels in Scotland -, edited by John Bonehill, Anne Dulau Beveridge, and Nigel Leask is published by Birlinn, pound, and available from the publishers or http:university-of-glasgow.myshopy collections hunterian-exhibition-catalogues products old-ways-new-roadsIts linked to an upcoming online exhibition at the Hunterian museum, Glasgowhttp:gla.ac.uk hunterian visit exhibitions virtualexhibitions oldwaysnewroads

title: scottish-icons-thought-scotland-without-redheads-enough-make-hair-curl
story: Scotland is a country much associated with red hair, as is Ireland. Supposedly, itrsquos a Celtic thing. But which of us has the most  Well, Google ldquowhich country has the most redheads, ken , and half the responses say Ireland and half Scotland.However, everyone seems to agree that one to two per cent of the Earthrsquos humanoid population is ginger. Scotlandrsquos redhead count is put at anywhere from  to  per cent and Irelandrsquos usually at  to  per cent. Probably theyrsquore just getting the two of us mixed up. If yoursquove ever had the misfortune of being abroad, yoursquoll know it happens, particularly in America. Or is it Canada At any rate, we seem to have the most in this corner of north-western Europe, probably because of all the clouds. Red hair and preternaturally pale skin prosper where sunlight is scarce. So why donrsquot Scandinavians and Russians have as many redheads  Well, they do have quite a few, particularly in south-west Norway and the Volga region.Indeed, redheads are all over the place. There are Melanesians with red hair. Jewish people have a reasonable incidence of red hair, and  per cent of their beards are ginger. Indeed, in medieval times, people with red hair were identied and persecuted as Jews by the highly questionable Spanish Inquisition.Red hair is multicultural. Even in England, ginger beards are common, often with head hair ostensibly a dferent colour. This is because the chin is further away than the top of the head from the Sun. Joke.Red hair is historical. It crops up all the time. Bacchus, the Roman god of bevvy, was depicted with red hair. It was the hair of the god. Redheads crop up frequently in Roman frescos. The Thracians were described, by the Greek poet Xenophanes, as having blue eyes and red hair.In that Iliad, the barnet of the aforementioned Achilles is most often translated as ldquoblond or ldquogolden but also sometimes ldquored or ldquotawny. In ancient Egypt, as well as the aforementioned Cleopatra , Ramesses II and the deity Set were said to have red hair.Closer to hame, the Roman historian Tacitus said: ldquoThe reddish hair and large limbs of the Caledonians proclaim a German origin. . Bear in mind, too, that you must take classical ethnography with a large vat of salt.Tacitus also described the Germans as having ldquofierce-looking blue eyes, reddish hair, and large bodies. As with the Caledonians, you have to ask: ldquoSurely, there were some wee sappy ones as well A fairly distinguished history, then. So why do redheads get it in the neck so much  If blond or blondeis so much admired, why is its close neighbour, ginger , so derided Well, it could just be the Scottish connection as wersquore the last people in the world at whom it is legitimate to laugh. Mean, unintelligible, ginger, yada-yada. But I suspect therersquos more to it than that.In medieval times, folk with red hair and green eyes were suspected of being witches, vampires or werewolves. Howling load of nonsense. In , the novelist Wilkie Collins noted ldquoa prejudice against red hair. In LM Montgomeryrsquos Anne of Green Gables, one character says of the redheaded heroine that ldquoher temper matches her hair.The fiery temper is a common stereotype. Mind you, studies claim redheads arenrsquot good with either heat or cold, which could make one pretty irritable.In the end, all prejudice on dumbo planet Earth comes down to folk being against anything dferent. Itrsquos the ultimate tribalism. In recent times, some redheads have tried getting ldquogingerism defined as a form of racism, though that hasnrsquot really taken off or been given official approval.Itrsquos true that people have been assaulted by nutters for having red hair. In , a ldquoKick a Ginger group was started on Facebook. In , Tesco produced a ridiculously cruel Christmas card that said: ldquoSanta loves all kids. Even the ginger ones. In , former Labour Equalities Minister Harriet Harman referred to Scottish Lib Dem Danny Alexander as a ldquoginger rodent. Singer Mick Hucknall says he repeatedly faced prejudice because of his hair colour and supports this being considered a racial-style crime.While itrsquos true that, by definition, redheads are a minority, Lord knows there are enough ldquoidentities on the go already. Is it a good idea to identy yourself primarily by your hair colour  ldquoHello, Irsquove got red hair.I get laughed at in the street for having a big red nose, but I donrsquot want ldquonasalism to be categorised as a hate crime, evenmy proboscis is part of my identity and I introduce myself at parties by saying: ldquoHello, Irsquove got a big red nose.Meantime, gingers have started fighting back by celebrating their beautul heids. Therersquos an annual Redhead Day in Holland, an Irish Redhead Convention, a redhead festival at the Gezer Kibbutz in Israel, and therersquos been a Ginger Pride march in Edinburgh.In , widely publicised research purported to show that both red and blonde hair would become extinct within  years. But this was a hoax based on wilful misinterpretation of genetic data.Again, in , it was claimed red hair in Scotland could die out as the country got sunnier with climate change. But does it work like that  Red hair entered the genes millennia ago, and therersquos a fair sprinkling of gingers in hot countries.For now, redheads ainrsquot going anywhere. And thank goodness. The thought of a Scotland without redheads is enough to make your hair curl.
