An iconic County Derry bakery has closed its doors after  years of production in the area. Hyndmans of Maghera was founded in  and had served the community of County Derry and beyond since with its baked goods. In an understated sign-off, the company simply printed a short message of thanks to all its customers on its final batch of products. “Thank you for your loyalty over  years,” it read. As news of the closure began to break online, hundreds of people shared happy memories of the company and its impact on the area. “This is a sad day for Maghera and indeed the rest of the local area and further afield,” said photographer David A Scott, leading the tributes. googletag.cmd.push “To many they are a institution, one that we all grew up with and one that will be sadly missed, not only by the customers but by the employees and their families who relied on them for their livelihood.” Former customer Paula McCormack said it was a terrible loss to the area. The gates of Hyndmans were locked last Friday. “I hope their workers have been able to get jobs. Their bread was delicious, especially fruit cake and their sodas were the best in the country.” However, fans of the bakery have been buoyed by news that a number of the bakerys staff will be continuing to work in the area. googletag.cmd.push Former Hyndmans staff Geoff Lee, Nigel Chambers and Sandra McDonald have linked up with Berties Bakery in Magherafelt, who announced the news the same day Hyndmans ceased production. “Hyndmans was an institution in its own right and we were sorry to hear of their closing,” they said. “Bertie’s is however delighted that we have been able to help three of their staff into key roles within our business and perhaps in some way we will be able to keep what was best about Hyndmans alive. “Sandra will be helping us with our new cake and traybake ranges, while Geoff and Nigel bring a wealth of experience particularly in Soda Breads.”     Former Hyndmans customers will be happy to see their favourite soda bread recipe live on.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Education Minister Peter Weir said: “My main objective has always been a fullof all pupils to school in line with public health advice. “Education has rightly been prioritised by the Executive for all the benefits that brings to our children and also for the longer term societal and economic benefits. googletag.cmd.push “Given the signicant disruption to our children’s learning, our focus now must be on educational recovery which will be critical to their future prospects. “With Executive support, I intend to invest in the necessary resources to help pupils address any disruption to their learning that they may have faced since the start of the pandemic.” Mr Weir said testing for school staff and older pupils will provide a signicant level of reassurance to education settings. “All settings will be reminded of the need for stringent adherence to good practice and additional signage will be provided to all schools to encourage people to comply with public health messaging. googletag.cmd.push “While it is for each family to decidethey wish fortheir child to participate in the testing, it will be of benefit to all those in schools for us to be able to break the chain of transmission of the virus by identying all those who may be asymptomatic. “My Department will continue to engage with school leaders and teaching unions to address their queries and concerns and to provide support and guidance as we move to a fullof pupils.” School meals and transport services will operate as normal for those schools and year groups where pupils are required to attend.       --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. .pm -JCB Triumph Hurdle The drying ground should see TRITONIC  to best effect for Alan King and Adrian Heskin. The Irish juveniles are strong in the shape of Quilixios and Zanahiyr but the manner in which Tritonic scooted clear of rivals in the Adonis at Kempton last time out really caught the eye on identical ground to this week. Even on soft with a touch of heavy on his prior start, he stayed on well to catch Casa Loupi at Ascot, the same horse he beat by  s in Kempton. There isnt much between the Irish pair based on form but I would lean towards Quilixios based on the way he finished out his race at Leopardstown, beating Saint Sam and Busselton, in February. googletag.cmd.push .pm -McCoy Contractors County Handicap Hurdle I wouldnt have a strong opinion on this race this year but I am tempted to have an eachway nibble on GOWEL ROAD  for Nigel and Sam Twiston-Davies. Hes won his last two starts quite easily and I like his form behind Bear Ghylls who ran well to be fourth behind Bob Olinger in the Ballymore here on Wednesday. Gowel Road finished just one and a half s behind Bear Ghylls at Ffos Las last November. .pm -Albert Bartlett Novices Hurdle Im going for STREETS OF DOYEN  who is proven over course and trip and has plenty to offer at a big price. He ran a stinker at Naas last time out wearing cheekpieces but I am hoping he can bounce back. Prior to that blip, he had put together four wins on the spin, including at Cheltenham last October when he beat Minella Encore by three and a half s on similar ground. That was over the same trip as todayand he even won over three miles on good ground in Gowran last year where he beat Flooring Porter by five s. Based on that, even though he got plenty of weight from his rival, there is more to come from him and he could still be on a decent mark. He is overpriced at   and can hopefully give a good account again. googletag.cmd.push .pm -Wellchild Cheltenham Gold Cup Chase AL BOUM PHOTO  will aim to emulate Arkle and Best Mate in winning three Cheltenham Gold Cups. I genuinely hope he does it for Willie Mullins who waited until this horses win in  to get his hands on the Gold Cup. He is the quintessential Gold Cup horse now and so lightly raced for that very reason to have him primed for Prestbury Park. He is going into the race this year with an identical prep to last year. In , he beat Acapella Bourgeois at Tramore on New Years Day before going to Cheltenham and winning the Gold Cup in March. Again in , he raced and won at Tramore on New Years Day he even beat the same horse in Acapella Bourgeois, only this time by further. It willtake something special to stop him. The story for the UK contingent will be the horse named after AP McCoy and trained by Nicky Henderson. CHAMPwas dead and buried, fully  s behind the leaders jumping the last in the RSA last season, but somehow managed to reel in and beat Allaho and Minella Indo on the line. The field couldnt run down Al Boum Photo up the hill in the last two years butone horse can, its Champ, and what a story it would be for AP McCoy and owner JP McManus. A Plus Tard represents the powerful Henry De Bromhead Racheal Blackmore pairing but I was disappointed with his run in defeat to Min in last years Ryanair. I cant make a strong enough case for anything  at the minute and   is a nice price for Al Boum Photo, perhaps the most under-celebrated horse in training.     .pm -St. Jamess Place Festival Challenge Cup Open Hunters Chase I think Billaway is the most likely winner of this race for Willie Mullins. He was second to the reopposing It Came To Pass in this last year but has been more consistent since. For me,   is too short and the Hunters chase is a race for an eachway bet for me. The winner was   last year to that will show you that anything can happen in this race. I am going for a bit of a risky one with MR MANTILLA . He was been picking up wins on the Irish point-to-point scene most recently beating Bellow Mome from the Willie Mullins yard at Stradbally in December. He beat Rewritetherules in November and the same horse was th behind Billaway at Down Royal a month later. Its not exactly a clean line to run through the form but Im willing to take a risk that Mr Mantilla is good enough to get involved here. The Hunters chase is always a fascinating race. Dont discount the Enda Bolger runners either. He won this race in  and  with On The Fringe. .pm -Mrs Paddy Power Mares Chase I think ELIMAY  has a touch of class about her and can get the better of this field for Willie Mullins, JP McManus and jockey Mark Walsh. She has won three out of her four chase starts with her only defeat coming at the hands of stablemate Allaho. She beat Shattered Love easily by five s at Naas last time out and a step up in trip and drying ground is all in her favour. Id be surprisedshe isnt odds-on before the start, particularly after Allahos exceptional win on Thursday. .pm -Martin Pipe Conditional Jockeys Handicap Hurdle Gentleman De Mee is the favourite for Willie Mullins but Im going for GALOPIN DES CHAMPS  from the same stable. This one is very interesting based on his run behind Appreciate It at Leopardstown. He was just nine s behind Tuesdays runaway winner of the Supreme and looking through the field, that was a very hot race. Ballyadam, second in the Supreme a few days ago, was second that day in Leopardstown while Blue Lord, who would have been second on Tuesday had he not fallen at the last, was third. The selection here was only a couple of s off that pair in Leopardstown and could be suited by the step up in trip here to M F. Longford Town  Derry City  Derry City’s season got off to the worst possible start as they were well beaten by newly-promoted Longford Town at Bishopsgate. Declan Devine’s team barely threatened throughout and they were second best to a Longford team who showed a great hunger and desire to win in their first game in the Premier Division since . City were almost caught out within two minutes as Ciaran Coll lost out in a challenge in midfield and the home side broke forward. Eoin Toal was faced with two Longford attackers and they worked it well, Rob Manley playing in Dylan Grimes, but with Darren Cole closing in, he curled his shot beyond Nathan Gartside but just wide of goal. googletag.cmd.push A spirted start from Longford got its reward just  minutes into the game when Grimes received the ball on the right corner of the penalty area, and easily got the better of Danny Lafferty before racing into the box and drilling the ball right across goal. A number of players bore down on goal and that may have affected Gartside, as the ball went untouched into the far corner of the net to give the home side the lead. It was a poor first half overall for Derry, but Longford goalkeeper Lee Stacey was finally called into action just before the break a City finally managed a shot on target. A cross from Fitzgerald fell for Parkhouse, who, off balance, did well to swivel and met the ball with his left foot, but the shot was too close to Stacey who was able to save. googletag.cmd.push Declan Devine made two substitutions at the break, with both Danny Lupano and Jack Malone coming on for Darren Cole and James Akintunde. But a series of half chances from corners aside, City rarely looked threatening. The game’s decisive moments came after the -minute mark when, moments after Malone went down in the area, Longford broke and won a free kick. Aodh Dervin went for the shot and Gartside could only parry straight into the path of Gorman, who couldn’t miss from two yards as Longford doubled their lead. It quickly could have got even worse for Derry as a confident Devin went for goal again – this time from  yards and his effort had Garside scrambling before it crashed back off the crossbar, as Longford threatened to embarrass Derry.      Teams LONGFORD: Lee Stacey, Paddy Kirk, Dean Zambra, Dylan Grimes, Rob Manley , Aaron O’Driscoll, Aaron Bolger , Aodh Dervin, Karl, Dean Byrne , Joe Gorman. DERRY CITY: Nathan Gartside, Danny Lafferty, Eoin Toal, Cameron McJannett , Darren Cole , Ciaran Coll, Ciaron Harkin, Will Patching, Will Fitzgerald , James Akintunde , David Parkhouse. It may have been Eoin Toal’s first game as captain, but he knows this feeling all too well. The -year-old has seen some dark days at Derry City, much worse then this in fact, so he is not going to panic over a poor performance and a poor result in the first game of a new season. That said, he still hates the feeling of losing and he admits that on this occasion, Derry City just weren’t good enough. “We started off slowly and gave away a few silly goals,” he reflected. “We knew that they were going to come out fast. They weren’t going to lie down to us and they got off to a really good start. I thought we had a few chances where we could have equalised but as the time went on, we weren’t making any clear-cut chances. It wasn’t to be today but hopefully it is in a few weeks’ time.” googletag.cmd.push This was Toal’s first game since being made permanent captain, and it did not go the way he had hoped in any sense.  “It wasn’t an ideal start but it isn’t about me,” he said. “It’s about the team, and we just need to stick together for the next game. “We want to win every game we play because we are playing for Derry City and it is a massive, massive club and I’ve said this before, but we don’t go anywhere to get beat. We just started off slowly and there were a few silly mistakes.” As an attacking force, City were almost non-existent against Longford, but Toal believes that luck did just not fall City’s way on a number of occasions, particularly from set-plays. googletag.cmd.push “We knew that maybe we could get a few goals from set-pieces because we’re a big enough side but it just didn’t fall for us tonight but on another night it just might,” he said. “I thought we went more direct after the second goal went in. I didn’t think the second goal was coming. I thought we had a few chances from set-pieces and maybe we could grab one. I thought we could grab one late on because we were on top but it wasn’t to be.” Looking ahead With this week’s game against Shamrock Rovers set to be postponed due to Nathan Gartside’s international call-up, Derry have a two-week break before their next game. Toal believes they can can use that time to understand what went wrong in Longford.     “I wouldn’t say that we have a lot to work on but we have time to reflect and analyse the game and analyse where we went wrong and look forward to the next game,” he continued. “We have two weeks before our next game so we have got to regroup and we have to stick together. The games are going to be coming thick and fast so we need to stick together. We know we are a new team and we’ll need time to come together but there are no real excuses – we started off slow and made two mistakes for the goals, and that should be better.” There were a number of surprise results on the first weekend of Airtricity League action, and Toal knows that the mood can sht quickly with victory in the next game.  “There’s no time to feel sorry for ourselves,” he agreed. “We’ll be back into training and we need to work together and stay together. There are going to be a lot of games coming up and the boys are going to be looking to get into the team and improve and that’s the main thing, to keep working hard.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Heres whats new on the streaming  this weekend: Operation Varsity Blues: The College Admissions Scandal  An examination that goes beyond the celebrity-driven headlines and es into the methods used by Rick Singer, the man at the center of the shocking  college admissions scandal, to persuade his wealthy clients to cheat an educational system already designed to benefit the privileged. Using an innovative combination of interviews and narrative recreations of the FBI’s wiretapped conversations between Singer and his clients, Operation Varsity Blues offers a rare glimpse into the enigmatic figure behind a scheme that exposed the s wealthy families would go to for admission into elite colleges, and angered a nation already grappling with the effects of widespread inequality. googletag.cmd.push Formula : Drive to Survive: Season     In the most dramatic season to date, fans will once again be taken behind the scenes, to witness first-hand how the drivers and teams battle it out for victory in a year like no other. The only problem  Everything they cooked was made of ice. When these two taste-buddies are suddenly hired as the freshest employees of a whimsical supermarket, they’re ready for the culinary adventure of a letime. With the help of friendly new faces like Mrs. Obama, the supermarket owner, and a magical flying shopping cart as their guide, Waffles and Mochi blast off on global ingredient missions, traveling to kitchens, restaurants, farms and homes all over the world, cooking up recipes with everyday ingredients alongside renowned chefs, home cooks, kids and celebrities.     Whether they’re picking potatoes in the Andes of Peru, sampling spices in Italy, or making Miso in Japan, these curious explorers uncover the wonder of food and discover every meal is a chance to make new friends. Waffles + Mochi is an exciting invitation to get kids and grown-ups cooking together in the kitchen and connecting to cultures around the globe. title: Bid to back conversion therapy ban
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council is to be asked to support a ban on so-called conversion therapy.A motion urging the local authority to act will be tabled at the organisationrsquos April meeting by Rowallane Alliance councillor Patrick Brown and formally seconded by Slieve Croob Sinn Fein councillor Cathy Mason.The politicians say that as part of the motion, they are seeking increased protection for the LGBTQI+ community across the district.The council is to be formally asked to ldquooppose the harm caused to the LGBTQI+ community in the past through the denial of rights and equal treatment and recognise that discrimination still occurs.In addition, the motion calls on the council to acknowledge and stand against the ldquoongoing harm the practice of conversion therapy brings to LGBTQI+ people.Politicians are also being asked to support calls to three Stormont ministers mdash Deirdre Hargey, Robin Swann and Naomi Long mdash to introduce an effective ban on conversion therapy within Northern Ireland, supported by a programme of work to help tackle these practices in all their forms.Politicians will also be urged to support calls to highlight and promote the continued support, counselling and advocacy local groups provide to members of the LGBTQI+ community.Cllr Brown said the ldquoabhorrent practice of conversion therapy is nothing short of a ldquoform of torture for LGTBQI+ iniduals and it is shocking it still exists in this day and age.ldquoA ban, backed up by legislation, will be yet another step towards creating a shared and equal society for the LGTBQI+ community in Northern Ireland, he said.Cllr Brown said it is imperative that local elected representatives show leadership on the issue to counteract what he described as ldquoharmful narratives from him and other prejudiced politicians.He added: ldquoI hope that the motion will be supported by my council colleagues, making it clear that we stand in solidarity with the LGBTQI+ community.Cllr Mason said she welcomed the work being done to ban conversion therapy.ldquoThe archaic practice of conversion therapy seeks to lsquodenormalisersquo and completely eradicate a personrsquos sexual orientation, gender identity or gender expression, she continued.ldquoConversion therapy is rooted in intolerance and bigotry, with those that conduct the therapies regularly exploiting the vulnerabilities of young people who are struggling with their sexuality.ldquoI welcome that the Communities Minister has committed to working to outlaw this deeply harmful and regressive practice.Cllr Mason said Sinn Feacutein Senator Fintan Warfield successfully brought forward a bill to outlaw conversion therapies in , explaining that his work with the LGBTQI community has resulted in the Irish Government now committing to legislate against conversion therapies in the near future.She added: ldquoIt is time to ban conversion therapies and to stand against hate.ldquoEvery inidual has the right to be free from discrimination, torture, inhuman and degrading treatment and any breach of these rights cannot be accepted. Sinn Feacutein will continue to work across the island of Ireland to eradicate hatred and to provide maximum support for LGBTQI+ citizens..prettyPhoto

title: Celebrations marking Chinese New Year
story: LOCAL cultural connections were made through an initiative to celebrate last monthrsquos Chinese New Year.The Chinese New Year  fell on Friday, February , with its new Lunar calendar beginning a year of the Ox.As part of this celebration Newry, Mourne and Down Council, through its PEACE IV Cultural Diversity Programme, helped celebrate the Year of the Ox Chinese New Year Virtual Festivalrsquo which was held between February ndash.The festival was delivered by Beyond Skin Blueprint PEACE IV Cultural Diversity Programmersquo which is a comprehensive ethnic minority cultural ersity programme working across the Newry, Mourne and Down area.The programme is supported by the European Unionrsquos PEACE IV Programme, managed by the Special EU Programmes Body .The event was a mix of on-demand and scheduled activities through music, movement, arts, food and the natural world celebrating Chinese culture and the human spirit of the strength in togetherness as we all navigate through these challenging times.A erse group of young people from the Newry, Mourne and Down area are continuing to meet and collaborate virtually with Chinese musicians in Northern Ireland, Singapore, China and New Zealand.Productions will be released later in the year with special guest musicians to include Stanley Ang, Stephen Huo, Ziyi Zheng, TammiQua, Hanyong Zhang  Danyang Cheng.Many new relationships have come about resulted from the programme. Killoughrsquos Kieron Black and David Lee, who is also from the district, collaborated on a music cookery production lsquoChinese Shanxi Punk Noodlesrsquo with Polly Hallett, who has been part of the lsquoTaste of The Worldrsquo Beyond Skin Blueprint Project.Kieron connected with musician Yihan Bin who also contributed to the Chinese New Year Virtual Festival. They are now starting out on a new collaboration project using music and art to build good relations between Northern Ireland and China..prettyPhoto

title: Covid
story: ITrsquoS exactly a year since the plug was pulled on the annual St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick amid increasing fears about the coronavirus.While there were no reported cases of the dangerous and deadly virus across the district at this stage, Newry, Mourne and Down Council said it was taking no chances and put the health of ratepayers front and centre by closing all public buildings as the virus spread rapidly across the globe.The Down Recorderrsquos front page headline on March  last year screamed out ldquoLockdown as leisure centres closed as they were deemed high risk locations, with warnings issued that the closures would be in place for months.Little did anyone realise that one year on, leisure centres, community centres and churches would remain closed, while non-essential retail, hairdressing salons and beauty parlours mdash which had been briefly allowed to reopen after the first lockdown mdash would still be shut.Sport has also been a major casualty of the pandemic, with beaches and parks also shut, while health chiefs temporarily closed accident and emergency services at the Downe Hospital as part of the South Eastern Trustrsquos response to the global emergency.As coronavirus cases and deaths soared, schoolchildren were sent home and have missed almost a full year of their education while, for many, Covid-, pandemic, unprecedented, lockdown, virus, test and trace, stay at home, social distancing, public health and R numbers, normally the stuff of science fiction, were now, chillingly, part and parcel of daily le.Many have lost loved ones to the deadly virus, businesses across the district face an uncertain future, with the fall-out from the pandemic set to impact on peoplersquos lives for decades to come.The roll out of a comprehensive vaccination programme has been hailed as a game-changer and indeed it is but, for many, the past  months have been filled with pain, heartache, suffering and loss.There is a light at the end of the tunnel as millions of people globally are vaccinated, but there is simply no room for complacency.On March , , the World Health Organisation declared that the Covid- public health emergency had become a pandemic. At this stage,  countries were affected, with , confirmed cases and more than , deaths.One year on, there have been  million confirmed cases globally and more than . million deaths from Covid-. In Northern Ireland, there have been , cases and over , deaths.Pandemic is not a word to use lightly or indeed carelessly, but when Prime Minister Boris Johnston mdash who himself who ended up in hospital with the virus mdash went on national television on March  last year, he appealed to people to stay at home to stop the spread of the virus.His appeal, broadcast by every major UK television and radio network, resulted in the immediate implementation of a series of unprecedented measures.Town centres across the district were locked down and deserted and people asked to act responsibly and do all they could to halt the spread of the disease by adhering to public health advice.In the wake of the Prime Ministerrsquos address, church leaders in Downpatrick and the surrounding area appealed for ldquoprayer, unity and calm as the coronavirus threat deepened.With public worship one of lockdownrsquos many casualties, a number of services moved on-line as churches embraced st century technology to provide people with much-needed hope at a time of need and reassurance.Newry, Mourne and Down Council, with the help of the Department for Communities, led from the front locally and was instrumental in helping distribute hundreds of food parcels to people across the area who were not allowed to leave home.The districtrsquos foodbanks had to respond to a major increase in demand, which was eased by the generosity of iniduals and groups across the district, with many sports clubs helping distribute food parcels.The pandemic united people like never before as the challenge of dealing with the global virus increased daily. Sadly, today, the UK has one of the highest per capita death rates from Covid in the world.As politicians prepare to slowly ease lockdown restrictions over the coming weeks, the district is bracing itself for ato normality, but exactly how normal le will be remains uncertain at this stage.The past  months have been le-changing, with people hoping that the light at the end of the tunnel will soon be shining like a beacon..prettyPhoto

title: Dancers make the best of lockdown
story: A CROSSGAR Irish dance school is trying to keep spirits raised during the lockdown.Owing to Covid restrictions, Irish dancers have not been allowed to attend classes in person since November last year.However this has not deterred Chris Owens, Bridget Madden and Brid McKinney, dance teachers at Scoil Rince an Chroiacute from motivating dancers who have continued to go from strength to strength.Briacuted said: ldquoIt has been extremely challenging times. Even when restrictions were eased in November we were not allowed toto our dance studio.ldquoHowever, rather than give into adversity, we have embraced as many aspects of digital technology as possible to teach our dancers.Consequently when Scoil Rince an Chroi were able to participate in a virtual online feis in March, they did so with resounding success.Chris explained: ldquoWhen the results came in, to say we are over the moon is an understatement.ldquoThe competition was open to dancers across Ulster across in all age groups. Our results were amazing including three championship wins,  top five championship places,  first places,  second places, nine third places. Overall we achieved  places in the top  per cent of competitions.Competing in an online feis is just the tip of the iceberg of the work Scoil Rince an Chroiacute have engaged with during lockdown.Using Zoom technology, dancers have continued to learn and perfect performances three times a week with their teachers.Through virtual learning forums and social s such as Google classroom and WhatsApp, daily challenges have been sent to dancers.Recognising the strain restrictions are having on young people, this forward thinking dance school implemented a lsquoMonday Mindfulnessrsquo programme during the February.A iety of activities were presented each Monday to keep spirits high including baking together and goal setting.The dance school also organised a class quiz for the whole family using Kahoot. The finale of the February activities was a live virtual meet with River Dance star Amymae Dolan.One dance parent, Helen, said: ldquoIrish dancing has been a godsend during restrictions for my daughter. She has really missed the social side of not being able to go to school. Being able to maintain her dancing has really helped in keeping her spirits up.Bridget Madden said the dance school was looking forward to getting dancers back into the studio.She added: ldquoWe are very proud of how much our dancers have been able to stay together, while forced apart.Fellow teacher Briacuted remarked: ldquoOur school name means to lsquodance from the heartrsquo and this virtual learning process has shown just how much young our young stars people love to dance..prettyPhoto

title: Daniel returns to Superstars series
story: ANNAHILT driver Daniel Harper has been chosen to continue as a member of the British Racing Driversrsquo Clubrsquos coveted SuperStars programme for .Recognised by the prestigious club as one of the most exciting young talents in British motorsport, the  year-old extends an association with the BRDC that began when he was selected to join their Rising Stars programme three years ago.Created in , the unique BRDC SuperStars programme aims to develop the most promising young drivers across all classes of racing, with former members including current Formula  stars George Russell and Lando Norris.Under the mentorship of programme director Andy Meyrick, BRDC SuperStars receive tailored help with mental and physical training, sponsorship, media and public relations.They are also able to network with other BRDC members at multiple events through the year.Daniel said: ldquoIrsquom really excited to be part of the BRDC SuperStars again this year.ldquoItrsquos a fantastic programme to be part of, and with only  drivers selected from across British motorsport, itrsquos an honour to be part of it and to continue representing the BRDC whilst racing in Germany.ldquoItrsquos been brilliant working with Andy [Meyrick] and the team so far and theyrsquove been giving me some great advice on how to progress in my career.ldquoHopefully therersquoll be some more opportunities to meet all the SuperStars this year and participate in more BRDC events.The announcement comes as Harper continues preparing for the  season and steps up to the highest class in modern GT racing for the first time.Hersquoll contest a full Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series season and the  Hour race in a BMW M GT.Daniel recently completed a two-month fitness and mental training camp at Formula Medicine in Italy, as well as heading to the Circuito Monteblanco in Spain to complete a week of development testing with BMW Motorsport.He has now ed to Germany with his team-mates in the BMW Junior Team to continue their preparations on and off track ahead of the opening round of the Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series on March .ldquoItrsquos been great to be back with the BMW Motorsport team, Daniel said.ldquoThe test in Spain was a great chance to all work together again and conduct some important development work for BMW in their M CS Racing and M GT cars.ldquoThe team at Formula Medicine put us through an extensive training camp and I personally feel more prepared than ever before heading into a new season.He added: ldquoWersquove got a busy few weeks ahead as we get acquainted with our M GT and BMW Team RMG ahead of the season opener. I canrsquot wait..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum comedian Kielty on issues around Brexit
story: DUNDRUM comedian Patrick Kielty has spoken out about how Northern Irish people have been viewed as an ldquoinconvenience during the Brexit negotiations and the ongoing sea border.The funny man turned presenter and documentary maker was speaking with Connor Philips on Radio Ulster ahead of his new show, Borderline: A Postcard From The Edge.The documentary was recorded in Patrickrsquos home town and was aired on Sunday evening as a BBC Radio  special about Brexitrsquos effect on Northern Ireland.He explained why he wanted to make the programme: ldquoThe reason I wanted to do it is because wersquove been told in Northern Ireland that we were someone rsquos problem, that we were an inconvenience.ldquoHow many headlines have you seen saying, lsquoHow can you solve Northern Ireland rsquo, lsquoHow can you solve this problem rsquoldquoGrowing up where we grew up, we sometimes had this inferiority complex that we should maybe be someone .ldquoWhat Irsquove realised, and what is at the heart of this show, is that we arenrsquot the problem. Because of what wersquove been through and the fact that we donrsquot want to go back there, you should maybe listen to us a bit more because wersquore maybe the solution to some of the decisions that yoursquore taking.Patrick said that he knew there was always going to be problems about either a land or a sea border emanating out of the Brexit solution, even though the region had voted against leaving the EU.ldquoWe could see this coming down the tracks in slow-motion and were watching everybody  going double-speed down the tracks to get to the place where,yoursquore from Northern Ireland, yoursquore going lsquono, no, norsquo, he explained.ldquoThatrsquos why I wanted to write this show. Also, it meant having a  to speak to the rest of the UK and say, lsquoActually, we might know stuff that you might think about listening torsquo.Patrick, whose father Jack was shot dead by loyalist paramilitaries in , has excelled at documentary making since his award winning show, My Dad, the Peace Deal and Me, was broadcast in .While now living in London with his presenter we, Cat Deeley, and their two son, Patrick was still living in the US at the time and admitted he could not watch it in fear of the response back home.ldquoThe responsibility was to tell the story of the place and howfar wersquod come, but also not to be self-indulgent because wersquove all been through it, he told Connor Philips.ldquoThe only thing I cared about was what people at home thought about it.To listen to Patrickrsquos programme, visit BBC Radio  Stand Up Specials..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 21%2C 2001
story: NEWCASTLE ndash Controversial plans to build several hundred new homes and apartments in Newcastle have this week been rejected by local planners.They have turned down three separate housing schemes for  hours and apartments planned for the Dundrum and Bryansford roads. Between them the applications had attracted considerable opposition within the Newcastle community.The planners have vetoed the substantial new-build schemes for the former Bouled caravan site at the Dundrum Road and at the former Brook Cottage Hotel site on the Bryansford Road.Planners have also rejected controversial plans to demolish two houses at the Bryansford Road to make way for  new apartments.It is likely the developers behind all three schemes will submit new proposals for the sites in the future.A Co Wexford based development company is behind the scheme to build  town houses and  apartments at the former Bouled caravan site which was sold for pound.m in .ARDGLASS ndash On Friday trawler men in Ardglass and Kilkeel will be forced to tie up their boats and their livelihoods for over a month.Fishing has been banned until the end of April by the European Union as part of a ban on cod fishing and the closure of sea areas where alternative species can be caught.Sweeping cuts in fish quotas, agreed by European fisheries ministers in December, has already left many trawler owners in debt and now the fishing ban will see further financial hardship.Local politicians have warned that unless the Department of Agriculture does something soon the coming month will be a disaster for the South Down fishing industry.KILLYLEAGH ndash Planning officials have confirmed that a public inquiry will be ordered into a major poundm house and marina development in Killyleagh.The news was confirmed this week with the rigorous public scrutiny expected to take place next year.Representatives from the firm behind the ambitious plan for the townrsquos Gocean area outlined the detail of the project during a meeting in Killyleagh last week.Senior officials from Ravenblack Developments believe the inquiry into the largest private project ever proposed for Down District, is likely to be heard in .They have also revealed the marina must be constructed before work starts on any of the new  homes and apartments at the  acre site, off the townrsquos Comber Road. The development plan also includes provision for a new cafe, craft and chandlery shops and a mill house.CROSSGAR ndash Parents in the Crossgar area have this week been asked to warn their children about the dangers of playing at the Glasswater River.The appeal has been issued by Down Council chairman, Mr Albert Colmer, who is concerned local kids have built a makesht bridge across the fast flowing waterway to gain access to nearby fields.He said the river, which flows behind the Lissara and Rademon private housing estate off the Saintfield Road, is very dangerous and could sweep away a young child.Mr Colmer is so concerned he is to contact the River Agency about the bridge and has already alerted local police that children playing in the area are placing their lives in great danger.KILCOO ndash A local councillor has criticised the Roads Service for the delay in constructing a footpath at Moyadd cottages on the outskirts of Kilcoo.Councillor Frank McDowell said it had been  years since he first raised the need for a footpath at Moyadd cottages.ldquoThe Road Service assured me in October last year that it would provide a footpath running from the village to Moyadd cottages before the end of the month, said Mr McDowell.ldquoHowever, it now seems progress on this work is being held up by current land dficulties. If work does not begin soon, the scheme may be deferred for some time as other priorities will take over in the new financial year which starts in April.DOWNPATRICK ndash A brand new gallery, depicting some exciting and innovative works of art, has received ministerial recognition this week.The dynamic talents of local artists were applauded last Thursday evening by Arts and Culture Minister, Michael McGimpsey, when he officially unveiled a craft exhibition in the new gallery at the St Patrick Centre.Mr McGimpsey was joined by guests, local politicians, council officials, centre staff and to the horror of some, a number of live snakes, to show their support to the local artists and the new multi-million pound centre.The minister said he was amazed by the skill of the artists whose gallery pieces celebrate the opening of the world centre for Saint Patrick.Mr McGimpsey pointed out that artistic talent within Northern Ireland has been repressed for over  years, therefore he was delighted to see such local talent on display for a large number of people to appreciate.DRUMANESS ndash River Agency officials are to be asked to put in place measures aimed at preventing rubbish finding its way on to agricultural land.At last nightrsquos meeting of Down Council, Mr Patsy Toman sought the support of his colleagues for a motion calling on the River Agency to prevent pollution in swollen rivers finding its way on to land owned by local farmers.He tabled his motion almost a month after incidents in the Drumaness and Teconnaught areas when a large amount of litter, which had been dumped into local rivers, ended up on farmersrsquo land which was flooded by the swollen waterways.Farmers in Drumaness area raised their concerns with Mr Toman at the time because none of the statutory agencies were prepared to help them.Mr Toman said as a result of the extreme wet weather before Christmas, the Drumaness river overflowed on to land owned by a number of local farmers.He explained that as a result, plastic bottles, bags, fridges and a selection of other debris was left strewn across land, posing a major threat to livestock and the local environment.CASTLEWELLAN ndash Planning officials have this week rejected plans for a new retail development on the outskirts of Castlewellan.They have refused to give the green light for the , sq. ft. development at the site of the Superlay Carpet factory because of the ldquoimpact it would have on existing businesses in the town centre.It is the first time planners have rejected a major retail development in Down District because of the impact it would have on established businesses and their decision not to approve the Dublin Road plan has been welcome by local councillor, Mr Eamonn OrsquoNeill.He said he is delighted the planners have refused to grant the application and welcomed their commitment to existing businesses in Castlewellan town centre.Mr OrsquoNeill, who expressed his concern about the proposal when the detail of the plan was announced in July , has endorsed the plannersrsquo view thatthe development was allowed to go ahead, it would be likely to have an ldquoadverse impact on the vitality and viability of existing businesses.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Ballynahinch Ulster Unionist councillor Harvey Bicker is quitting local politics, it has been confirmed.The Spa businessman, who has been a councillor for over four years, will not be contesting the forthcoming local government elections.News of Mr Bickerrsquos decision not to seek re-election comes on the eve of his partyrsquos announcement of who it will select for the May contest, with speculation mounting it plans to spring a surprise by unveiling three candidates.Mr Bicker is the only Ulster Unionist politician from the Ballynahinch area on Down Council and the partyrsquos decision to field three candidates in the area in the hope of securing a second seat will raise a few eyebrows..prettyPhoto

title: Huge rise in fly tipping
story: THE scale of the districtrsquos fly-tipping epidemic has been laid bare this week.Shocking new figures have revealed that there was a % increase in the number of reported incidents last year compared to the previous  months.Newry, Mourne and Down Council confirmed at a meeting last night that there were  reported fly-tipping incidents last year, compared to  in .Between  and  over , fly tipping incidents were reported to the local authority while, incredibly, during the first two months of this year, council officials have already received reports of  fly-tipping incidents across the district.During the height of the coronavirus pandemic between March and December last year, there were  illegal dumping incidents, compared to  over the same period in .The figures made public at last nightrsquos meeting of the councilrsquos Neighbourhood Services Committee revealed that the average number of fly tipping incidents across the district rose from  each week to  for a period last year, before dipping back to .News of the scale of the fly-tipping issue comes after a large consignment of tyres was dumped illegally last week outside Killyleagh.Around  tyres were found dumped at the Scaddy Road and Greystown Road, while, there was more fly-tipping at an illegal dumping hot spot at Ardilea, near Clough, where an old washing machine and other household debris was dumped.In a bid to call time on the illegal dumpers, the local council has employed additional enforcement officers and drawn up a new plan to deal with fly-tipping and dog fouling issues.In addition, two more seasonal enforcement staff are to be appointed next week as the local authority braces itself for a busy spring and summer.Council officials have also confirmed that they are exploring the possibility of using mobile CCTV to catch those who fly-tip which could include enforcement staff wearing body-cams as part of an evidence gathering initiative.In the summer, a new awareness programme to highlight fly-tipping and dog fouling issues across the district will be rolled out by the local authority, while consideration is being given to introducing a new community fund to support anti-littering and dog fouling initiatives across the district.During the last financial year the local authority issued  fixed penalty notices to litter louts, with  of the offenders paying up. Eight fixed penalty notices for dog fouling were issued over the same period.Rowallane area councillor Billy Walker, who was alerted to the dumped tyres outside Killyleagh, said there were people who viewed secluded rural areas as open air dumping grounds.ldquoThis behaviour must stop, he declared. ldquoThe tyres dumped outside Killyleagh had been left in three dferent areas and I hope that whoever was responsible for this illegal dumping incident will be caught and that the courts will impose a penalty which sends out a clear signal that this behaviour will not be tolerated and has no place in any civilised society.ldquoCouncil officers visited the Scaddy and Gregstown roads looking for evidence and the issue has also been reported to the Environment Agency. Incidents of this nature are happening all too often across the district.Cllr Walker says there have been recent reports of tyres dumped where in the Rowallane area including Ballynahinch and Saintfield.ldquoThe number of fly-tipping incidents reported across the district makes uncomfortable reading and the ironic thing is that those responsible for dumping waste end up paying for its removal through the rates and taxes, he said.ldquoIt is clear that a van or lorry was used to dump the tyres in Killyleagh and I would appeal to anyone who knows anything about this incident to contact the council or the police. This behaviour must not be allowed to continue.Cllr Walker said while local authority officials are doing their best to get on top of the fly-tipping issue, their efforts are being hindered by some in the community who have no respect for their own areas and communities.He added: ldquoFly-tipping and dog fouling issues are a scourge on our district and while additional enforcement officers have been recruited, the battle to address illegal dumping starts with those who engage in such behaviour. They have to stop..prettyPhoto

title: Kathryn hangs up scrubs
story: POLITICIAN, we, mother, PhD student and for the last year, a frontline healthcare worker ndash Kathryn Owen has decided to hang up her scrubs for good.The DUP councillor from Saintfield has, in her own words, reached her point of exhaustion after ing to hospital wards as a nursing auxiliary throughout the Covid- pandemic.ldquoI am done, I know that Irsquom done. Itrsquos reached a point where you have to say to yourself, thatrsquos enough, said Mrs Owen, who recently has been switching shts as a nursing assistant from working in a hospital vaccination team and the Nightingale at Belfast City Hospital.ldquoI ed in March last year, solely to help out during the Covid pandemic, and almost a year to the day, Irsquove decided to call it a day.No one expected the pandemic to be this long, but there are finally green shoots of hope.ldquoItrsquos all come at the right time. I never expected to be caught up in all of this, she continued. ldquoI was doing my PhD and le was great as I had just become a brand new councillor and the learning curve of being a councillor was vertical. Then all of a sudden, it was bam, my le was turned upside down.The  year-old said that her decision to stop working in the NHS is the right one for her, but one which has left her very torn.ldquoI didnrsquot know how much more I had to give to be honest, with juggling home schooling, although hopefully that will come to an end soon, doing my PhD, and being a councillor.ldquoIrsquove been spinning so many plates for so long, it got too much. I still feel that I should have been able to do more so therersquos still gut-wrenching guilt but I had to make a decision.The former army medic revealed that one of the most emotional mdash and inspirational mdash times for her was being with her  year-old father Alan Moore receiving his first vaccine jab last month.ldquoIrsquom a self-proclaimed daddyrsquos girl and when he got his vaccine, I was sitting there watching, like a silly puppy, and to hold his hand while he got the vaccine was one of the best feelings Irsquove had in a long time. Her mother Shirley has also since been vaccinated.The nursing assistant admits that she feels that she has deserted her nursing colleagues, who are all exhausted, but knows that her husband Steven,  year-old son Thomas and  year-old daughter Grace need her full attention.ldquoThere were times as I was doing my PhD or council work Thomas would have needed help with his Politics essays or Grace with long ision, with my poor husband having to be husband and we to support us all, she said.ldquoThe only time I got with my family outside of my work commitments was an hour and a half in the evening, .pm was TV time for us all.Mrs Owen worked in Craigavon Hospitalrsquos PPE Village, for the donning and doffing of personal protection equipment, the Covid wards, as well as few shts in the hospitalrsquos cardiology wards.Aside from devoting herself to her council role and family, she hopes to complete her PhD in Cardiology before taking up a role in medical research or health policy making, along with continuing to inspire and encourage more women into politics.However, she paid a special word of thanks to all those who helped her over the last  months.ldquoItrsquos time for me to simply le again but I would like to pay my gratitude to my colleagues, Cllrs Billy Walker and Glyn Hanna, who stepped up to help me council-wise, along with party colleagues Jim Shannon and Peter Weirrsquos offices.ldquoIt was not only my family who supported me by taking the pressure of me, as well as my constituents, who all really tried to keep the pressure of me and I really appreciated that..prettyPhoto

title: Natasha gets recognition for writing and activism
story: A KILLYLEAGH teenager has been making her views known and her voice heard more than usual during lockdown.Natasha Manganaro, an A-Level student at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle, has just been shortlisted for publication in theFighting Words Supplement .Natasha has just completed a storytelling course for performance with Word of Mouth and will be representing the Northern Ireland Commissioner for Children and Young Peopleat the Stormont Bill of Rights Committee next Wednesday.Nat, as she prefers to be called, is also a rising playwright and in January, her radio drama was performed by the Derry Players.In the midst of all this, she is also completing her A-Levels and has won herself an unconditional offer to study Creative Writing and Drama at the University of Bath.Throughout her time at Shimna, Nat has been a youth activist and said her first steps into the world of campaigning was by joining her schoolrsquos Amnesty group.ldquoI wasnrsquot as tuned into activism and dferent movements as I should have been, but after joining Amnesty my eyes were completely opened. After that I just kept getting involved in everything I could NICCY Youth Panel, UK Youth parliament, anything, she said.ldquoWhenever yoursquore dferent, like for me growing up half Italian, having a wacky sense of style, and generally just not fitting with the norm, almost adds a driving force to activism.She recalled that one of her first campaign in school was to gather petition signings at school assemblies on behalf of a Saudi blogger Ra Badawi who was sentenced to , lashes.Nat also organised the lsquoMake Your Markrsquo campaign with the UK Youth Parliament at her school and took part in making the schoolrsquos Religious Voices and Refugee Voices documentaries.She also got a taste of politics at close quarters by going to Prime Ministerrsquos Question Time and visiting the Houses of Parliament with her Politics class last year. Nat has also appeared twice on BBCrsquos Spotlight programme discussing young peoplersquos issues.She explained further: ldquoI am a member of the NICCY youth , campaigning for children and young peoplersquos rights across Northern Ireland and the UK Youth parliament. I did make a back bench speech on the impact of bullying on a young personrsquos mental health.ldquoI hosted a lsquoWriting to your MP local politician workshoprsquo over lockdown, with ONE Campaign and attended climate change strikes and a Black Lives Matter protests and have sent out emails to local politicians campaigning for a ban on conversion therapy.Nat sees a long link between her writing creativity and her activism.ldquoWithin my writing I always try and include some topics of activism. Irsquom currently developing awhich mentions the death of journalist Lyra McKee , she said.ldquoI wrote another one which focuses heavily on The Stonewall Riots. Activism is quite literally at the core of every creative thing I do.ldquoMy radio play, Undercover punks, was professionally produced by the Derry Players through the Fighting Words Right Twig programmeldquoCreativity is, for me, the best form of self-expression. The arts tell things in another language that allows everyone to understand sometimes it can be an even more powerful form of activism than all .Some of the most pressing issues for Nat now is campaigning for young people to get the vote at the age of , banning conversion therapy, and how CCEA tackles the A Level and GCSE grading for this year after the lockdown.While her future will be taken up with university over the next few years, Nat intends to still pursue her activism.ldquoI hope to promote dferent issues, topics, and movements through my writing. I will also keep attending protests, gatherings, any of the organisations I am currently involved with, and more in the future. I will campaign while there is still a fight..prettyPhoto

title: New home for Newcastle FC
story: NEWCASTLE Football Clubrsquos ambitious plans for a new home have been given a huge boost.An application by the club to relocate has been approved by planners and is expected be confirmed by Newry, Mourne, and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee next week.The club hopes to leave its current home at Shimna College and move to Church Hill, off the Castlewellan Road, just outside the town.The exciting development involves the construction of three pitches, including a full-sized intermediate standard grass pitch. There will be two other pitches, one of which will have anarticial G surface.The club is also planning to build a clubhouse along with seating for spectators, fencing and car parking facilities, as well as a new access.Club officials are currently tight-lipped about their plans, which would represent a major boost for soccer in the Newcastle area.The clubrsquos first team has enjoyed considerable success, completing a memorable double in the - season when it won the Cochrane Corry Cup and Division B of the Amateur League.Newcastle won Division A in - and Division IB in  . The club currently plays Division A.The club also has two other teams which compete in the Newcastle League..prettyPhoto

title: No Jimmy’s 10 meeting once again for runners
story: SUNDAY, as well as being Motherrsquos Day, should have been the date for East Down ACrsquos annual flagship race mdash Jimmyrsquos .However, anyone looking out for the colourful spectacle of runners forging down Market Street on Sunday morning would have been sorely disappointed.Normally the St Patrickrsquos weekend and Jimmyrsquos  race day coincide and the town of Downpatrick welcomes a multitude of visitors to take part in the festivities.The popular road race is the culmination of months of planning with over , people thronging East Down ACrsquos club rooms eager to pick up their numbers, to discover what colour the T-shirt will be and hoping they might get a peek at the tables groaning with post race treats.It is an action-packed day where runners of high calibre might be out to snatch a prize or score a personal best time while others might be running their first K distance or perhaps raising money for charity or just be taking part for the sheer joy of running in a big crowd.With a relay event on offer as well it caters for those who are not quite ready for K and there are also many who walk the course. Something for everyone.It is extremely hard work to organise, but seeing the smiles of those taking part and hearing the cheering onlookers makes it all worthwhile.Roll back to the same weekend in  and it was a bleak day in the history of the race. Just like yesterday the place was deserted.Jimmyrsquos K has been in the calendar since  and has taken place every year since with only two hitches ndash foot and mouth in  and an lsquoout of the bluersquo snow day in  caused postponement, but only by a short space of time.The pandemic that struck in  totally overshadowed these minor interruptions.Covid- had been appearing in the headlines for a few weeks by then, but initially it seemed to be a remote problem confined to China and other places overseas, yet suddenly it was on our doorstep and a very real threat.The powers that be were issuing bulletins to inform us all of what restrictions might be imposed and yet it still seemed asthe race would go ahead as there was no direct order to cease.The race committee met daily and then had almost hourly gatherings as the situation closed in.When schools and work places were told to prepare for closure and the government was using the word lockdown, it was decided that it was best to communicate to all that the race would not take place.After doing all the hard work, it was a bitter pill to swallow but taken in the context of what some had to face in their lives, it was just a fact of le and a line was drawn. We all hunkered down and waited for the storm to pass.Little did we know then that a year later that we would still be under orders to socially distance, to work from homepossible and to avoid unnecessary journeys, etc.We would have found it hard to envisage how work and home le would be impacted and that sport would be universally curtailed.Initially we had rolled over all the entries from the  race to the corresponding date in , but in December it was obvious that a race in March would not be feasible.We took a decision to push the date back in the hope that a race in  would still happen. At that time, we chose June  as the new date, but the recent lsquoRoadmap to Recoveryrsquo has caused a rethink.The good news is that with the uptake of the vaccine and the fall in numbers regarding infection rates and hospital cases, things are moving in the right direction, but by stalling for a couple more weeks, we feel that there will be further easing of limits.We are awaiting the next Executive update in the hope that club training might be able to take place in the not too distant future and that competition will follow. So we have rebooked a date for Jimmyrsquos  mdash Sunday, June .All  entrants have been carried over and East Down AC greatly appreciate the understanding of the runners and other clubs.We know that it is not ideal that changes are made and we all prefer certainty and being able to train for a set goal, but we are trying to make the best out of a dficult situation.Racing has been thin on the ground in the last  months so organisers and athletes are equally keen to get back in action. might seem distant now, but the photos in the archives remind us of the good times.That year was a bumper entry and the race was a huge success. We have to hold on to those memories for now and tell ourselves that we will enjoy it all the more for the long wait.The club is very excited at the prospect of hosting old friends and new and it will be a happy day for all concerned.Once all the deferrals are accounted for, It is hoped that extra places will also go on sale.These will be advertised in the Down Recorder, as well as at www.eastdownac and on the EDAC Facebook page, so keep an eye out..prettyPhoto

title: Peace maze among top worldwide attractions
story: THERE will be no surprise locally that the stunning peace maze in the sweeping grounds of Castlewellan Forest Park has been included in a prestigious list of post-lockdown international attractions.Previously listed among ldquoonce famous world attractions, the maze commands stunning views towards the majestic Mourne Mountains sweeping down to the Irish Sea.Travel website Loveholidays has been looking into Guinness World Record books to discover previous record-holding places to visit.The site, which lists eight attractions across Europe, Asia and North America, features Castlewellan Forest Park, where the maze is considered to have one of the most outstanding tree and shrub collections in Europe.And it is in good company in the list, joined by the CN Tower in Toronto and the Stade de France in Paris among others. The website said there were some truly breathtaking spots across the world and some so good, that they achieved world records.But what about those ldquoonce famous landmarks that previously held records, it asked, comparing Guinness World Record data from previous editions from , ,  and .This research revealed where these once famous landmarks are located so people could ldquogo and show them some much deserved love.The website states: ldquoIf yoursquore ready for adventure, a hedge maze makes the perfect day out with the family and Northern Ireland has one that certainly offers a challenge.ldquoThe maze at Castlewellan Forest Park once held the world record for the largest, permanent hedge maze in the world. Itrsquos . acres with over two miles of hedges, and is made up of , yew trees.The website added: ldquoIt has since lost its title to Chinarsquos labyrinth Yancheng Dafeng Dream Maze in . This huge maze has a total size of , square feet and its longest path stretches nearly six miles.The peace maze is one of Northern Irelandrsquos most popular tourist attractions, comprising , yew trees, many of which were planted by people from all over Northern Ireland during December of .The maze was commissioned to beautully symbolise the peace and reconciliation efforts of Northern Ireland in the past century and provides an opportunity for visitors to enjoy a weaving walk through the paths and trails surrounded by the impressive back of the Mournes..prettyPhoto

title: Saul looking to the future
story: SAUL GAC has unveiled ambitious plans to upgrade its facilities.The far-sighted club is seeking planning permission for a package of major improvements, including a synthetic pitch and new floodlighting.Also included are a new spectator stand and scoreboard along with the construction of a commentary building.The total cost of the improvements is estimated at between pound, and pound,.A spokesman for the club said the plans were intended to ensure the continued development of the club both on and off the field in the coming years.He said that new floodlighting would enable the club to hold games in the evening, provide a facility for county championship games and increase the usage during the winter months for all ages.He said the floodlighting project, estimated at between pound, and pound,, would also include the lighting of the clubrsquos popular community trail.ldquoThe lighting of the trail would bring light into darkness for the many users of the trail in the evening hours and help maximise the trail for the local community.He said the club have also identied the need for a G playing surface in the local area through its membership.ldquoGiven the ever increasing popularity of the clubrsquos youth teams and one of the biggest Cul Camps in County Down, the club see the benefit of having a G surface that provides a longer-term surface for all in the club to utilise and sustain the growing numbers.ldquoThe project is to deliver a training size G playing surface, costing between pound, to pound,.He continued: ldquoSaul last year won the Intermediate Championship and with the Senior Championship to look forward to when sport s, the club are looking to improve the digital connection for live game streams through a proposed commentary building that will enable the club to bring the sport to homes across the world.ldquoIn addition to the commentary building, the club are looking to build a spectator stand to host the many local supporters and travelling visitors to the ground. For the commentary building, spectator stand and new scoreboard it will cost around pound, to pound, to complete.The spokesman said the club was also planning to improve its hall and gym and to carry out a planting scheme.ldquoThe gym is extremely popular with both club members and public members as it is easily accessible and open  , he said.ldquoThe hall provides great indoor use for training, parties, events, bowling and many community activities. The club are looking to extend the range of facilitates available to the community.The spokesman stressed that all of the projects were subject to planning permission being approved and would be completed in a phased approach as grant funding became available.He added: ldquoThe club are extremely excited by the future development plans and the great asset all will be to the club members, but also to the community that has signicantly supported the clubs throughout the years..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick’s Day was always the most special day in our household
story: TV presenter Eamonn Holmes has spoken of his connection to Saint Patrick as part of a new podcast series from the Saint Patrick Centre.The Belfast-born broadcaster revealed that Patrick was his confirmation name and recalled how his family loved to celebrate St Patrickrsquos Day with a day out by the sea.Holmes spoke to Martina Purdy, a former BBC correspondent, and Elaine Kelly, a former barrister, both of whom were Adoration Sisters for five years.ldquoSaint Patrickrsquos Day was always the most special day in our household, said Holmes. ldquoMy father, a working man, a carpet fitter, always took St Patrickrsquos Day off. We always went to St Patrickrsquos mass on Donegall Street.This was followed by trip to Bangor, a fish supper from Longrsquos and his father enjoying a few drinks at the pub.Holmes recounted that one year his father quit his job rather than work on St Patrickrsquos Day. ldquoMy father said he wasnrsquot doing it. And he consulted with my mother and she was with him.He also revealed that his we, Ruth Langford, was born on St Patrickrsquos Day.Tim Campbell, director of the Saint Patrick Centre, said it was wonderful to have Holmes as the first guest and looked forward to many more podcasts between now and next Saint Patrickrsquos Day.ldquoWe will be featuring Belfast comedian Tim McGarry next month. Today [St Patrickrsquos Day] Martina and Elaine have interviewed Patrick Dexter who has won world attention playing his cello in his garden from County Mayo. Today he is also playing virtually at Irish embassies around the world. He plays two beautul piece for our podcast.Holmes began the podcast with a friendly serenade, singing lsquoSistersrsquo, the old song by Irving Berlin.He kindly agreed to take part in the podcast after Martina contacted him on Twitter after he tweeted he would like to laugh about rubbish and talk nonsense with new people.ldquoI was chancing my arm but was delighted that Eamonn agreed to do the podcast, Martina said.ldquoWe had a great chat with him. He spoke of his connection to Saint Patrick and also some of the problems in the media today. He has a great sense of humour and was very generous.Elaine added: ldquoIt was a lot of fun to speak to Eamonn and I never dreamed I would do be doing that. My mum and my family loved watching him on UTV when I was growing up. I was really impressed with his warmth, his humour and his professionalism. And how he included both of us in the chat.Holmes has interviewed many celebrities including Hollywood stars Dustin Hoffman, Meg Ryan and John Travolta but said the personality he would still most like to interview was the Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton.His remarks come amid turmoil over splits in the Royal family involving the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.ldquoI think I would be interested in her take on everything which you wouldnrsquot get. I think other people have had their say and everybody has got a view and an opinion, he said.ldquoAnd I think when you look at people who just get on with it and know what it is to serve hellipas opposed what it is to give orders, you look at someone like her and you think you know you could be a dferent person and you have accepted this role.Holmes said he had observed that celebrities with an entourage were the most problematic. He also shared his views on the media, his le and his attitude to an afterle.The podcast can be accessed on Saint Patrickrsquos Centre webpage www.saintpatrickcentre..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes to highly popular athlete
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to Cloughrsquos Glenn McBride who has died at the age of .Glenn, who passed away peacefully in the Belfast Cancer Centre on Saturday, was a talented sportsman and a highly popular member of Down Special Olympics Club in Downpatrick and Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club in Newcastle.He particularly enjoyed soccer and basketball and played both to a high standard. He won a basketball gold medal with Team Ulster at the Ireland Games in .He also won a soccer gold medal with Team Down at the Area Games in Belfast in  and was a member of the Ulster soccer team at the Ireland Games the following year.Lawrence Power, head coach of the Down Special Olympics Club football team, said he learned of Glennrsquos death with great sadness.ldquoOur sympathies go to Glennrsquos family at this time, he said. ldquoGlennrsquos memory will always be remembered in the Down Special Olympics Club and especially with the football team. He was a young man who had a love for football and basketball. ldquoMr Power said he encouraged Glenn to become a football coach and to take part in an Irish FA coaching programme.He also paid tribute to IFA development officer Seamus Heath for assisting Glenn with his training.He continued: ldquoGlenn had a good attitude both on and off the field and would encourage the players around to do likewise. He was a leader and a player who always gave one hundred per cent and the players respected him.ldquoWhenever this pandemic clears we willto our football training sessions with hardened hearts knowing that our friend and player will no longer wear the number  shirt. Rest in peace.Also paying tribute to Glenn, Mr Heath described him as a friend and said he would be sorely missed.He recalled: ldquoI first met Glenn when I coached once a week at Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick over  years ago.ldquoIt was there that his football started to blossom as they kept reaching the Northern Ireland schools finals.ldquoGlenn had a desire for winning and that competitive edge drove him and his teammates to great success in the schools competitions.ldquoAs he grew into manhood he excelled for Football Clubs United under Cyril McKinney and Harry Walsh and Down Special Olympics with Frank Donnelly and Lawrence Power and played in high profile game both at home and abroad.Mr Heath said that as he got to know Glenn better they formed a bond and became friends for le.He went on: ldquoAs I travelled around the district coaching and managing, Glenn became part of the football scene.ldquoHe worked with me in local schools, football camps and assisted me when I took his own teams for their weekly sessions.Where ever we went he left a positive and lasting impression. It got to a stageI turned up at places without him they would ask, wherersquos Glenn ldquoMy memories of Glenn will always be one of someone you could take anywhere with you.His manners were impeccable, he could hold a conversation, he cared for his friends and team-mates and his infectious smile and laugh was there for all to witness.Glennrsquos supportive family circle were a credit to everyone. When I required him to be ped off somewhere or collected they were there at any given minute and the warmth of their support was outstanding.Mr Heath added: ldquoI have lost a friend for now and our district will miss him sorely, but we will all stay together to celebrate his le and keep his memory in the present.The sympathy of the community is extended to Glennrsquos family..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres.
